column13:
'

Industry Pain Points

  • Cost pressures
  • Slow
column14:
fragmented business processes
  • Security
  • Large workforce with many disparate employee profiles and departments
  • Content-laden
  • Poor communication

    • Liferay Solution

    • Lowest total cost of ownership (TCO)
    • Workflow & fine grained permissioning allow different users to access specific levels of permissions and access to documents and applications 
    • Application integration
    • Built-in CMS with centralized document library
    • Built-in collaboration suite provides an out-of-the-box platform for communication
    ]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1719&t=1201128422126 '

column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="company-image" type="image">
    <dynamic-content id="10624">/image/journal/article?img_id=1708&t=1189532948847</dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="company-link" type="text">
    <dynamic-content><![CDATA[http://www.ixarm.com/Platform-hub]]></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="company-link-name" type="text">
    <dynamic-content><![CDATA[www.ixarm.com/Platform-hub]]></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="quote" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><p><em><font size="3">Liferay is now a serious player in defense space. Many projects are looking at EPNG as a critical reference for an infrastructure portal. </font></em></p><p><font size="3">--Geoffray Gruel
column15:
Ippon Technologies</font></p></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><p><strong>Company Profile</strong></p> <p>Created in 1961 as the ministerial delegation for armament
column16: the DGA is an organization belonging to the French Ministry of Defense. Its main purpose is to ensure the competitiveness
column17: quality and safety of French Defense equipment.</p> <p>DGA responsibilities include:</p> <ul> <li>Equipping the French armed forces</li> <li>Leading Defense programs encompassing procurement
column18: testing and evaluation. <ul> <li>DGA manages 78 defense programs in the phases of design and manufacturing.</li> <li>In 2005
column19: the DGA placed &euro;10 billion worth of industry orders.</li> </ul></li> <li>Preparing the future <ul> <li>Imagining possible future scenarios and guaranteeing that required technologies and expertise will be available.</li> </ul></li> <li>Promoting defense equipment exports</li> </ul> <p><strong>Challenge</strong></p> <p>The research
column21: manufacturing and support of the defense programs involve the daily exchange of a wide range of information amongst the members of the defense community. In addition to the French Armaments Procurement Agency (DGA) members include the armed forces
column24: and government financial departments.</p> <p>With this in mind
column25: the DGA set out to create a collaboration platform to offer these players a rational
column26: unique and advanced communications solution for all their exchanges of technical
column27: contractual and financial data. Key requirements for the platform included:</p> <ul> <li>an easy to use collaboration platform (Portal)</li> <li>easy to configure secured communities</li> <li>an easy to configure process engine</li> <li>a wide range of integrations for connecting external information systems</li> <li>a high level of security (strong authentication with smart cards X509 v3 client certificates)</li> <li>a private network (European Network eXchange)</li> </ul> <p><strong><strong>Resolution</strong></strong></p> <p>After a long evaluation and benchmarking process administered by the DGA
column28: Liferay was chosen by Ippon Technologies<a href="http://www.ippon.fr/">www.ippon.fr</a>- to serve as the de facto portal infrastructure for the DGA collaboration platform. Designed and developed by Ippon
column30: EPNG also employed BEA Weblogic Integration for its workflow engine and EAI with IPDiva for its secure reverse proxy.</p> <p>By leveraging Liferay''s capabilities
column31: Ippon Technologies was able to implement:</p> <ul> <li>Strong authentification / authorization with LDAP and certificates<o:p></o:p></li> <li>Detailed and secure community architecture</li> <li>Strong integration with Weblogic Integation</li> </ul> <p>Currently
column32: there are 20 Portlets in production on top of Liferay including:</p> <ul> <li>Private mailing systems</li> <li>Per collectivity forums and enterprise chat</li> <li>Per collectivity document library</li> <li>Usage statistics</li> <li>Digital signature and notarizing</li> <li>Workflow administration (with access to Weblogic Integration configuration).</li> <li>External applications access (connection through IPDiva Mediation Server).</li> </ul> <p>Moreover
column33: unique customization possibilities from Liferay Portal (engine tuning) will allow EPNG to scale easily and support wide adoption from the extensive defense community.</p> <p>Also
column34: as of August 2007 (11 months into production)
column35: almost 500 users have been registered on EPNG
column39: EADS
column40: DCN). Twenty external applications are also now connected like online part stocks for aircrafts allowing military forces to access and order parts direct from the suppliers.</p> <p>EPNG is connected to the Ministry of Defense Intranet allowing 100
column41:
000+ users to access its services.</p></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1751&t=1201073749970 “Now positioned for development as AutoZone’s enterprise portal
column15: enabling company-wide task management and linking AutoZone’s diverse employee base together in a common community
column16:
furthering strengthening the company’s unique business culture.”

– Loni Glancy
column19:
AutoZone

]]> Company Profile

AutoZone (NYSE:AZO) is the nation''s leading retailer and distributor of automotive parts and accessories with more than 4
column22: and Mexico. Each store carries an extensive line of new and remanufactured hard parts
column23: maintenance items and accessories for cars
column25:
vans and light trucks. 

Challenge

AutoZone’s communications environment needed a significant overhaul in 2004. Nice to know information competed equally with need-to-know tasks. Non-management store employees received an average of 30-40 e-mail messages a week
column26: while management received 20-30% more. Of these messages
column27:
only about 10-15% required specific actions.

Policies and procedures were available electronically and were printed and filed haphazardly. There was no way to centrally track whether a policy had been reviewed and understood by employees. Training materials were disconnected from training certifications with a high potential for pencil-whipping to occur. Determining one’s benefits standing required a phone call during headquarters’ office hours when stores were busiest.

Management reporting arrived via e-mail
column29: in the mail and through a custom-built
column30: unsupported .html environment. It was clear that a single source for all store information and tasks was needed and that it had to be easy to use
column31: available on demand 24x7
column32: and easy to maintain without significant IT resources. In addition
column33: the software had to be thin enough to run on Neoware thin clients
column34: which were installed in every store. The first thins had just 233 Mb of memory and no hard drive. Later systems were larger
column35:
but continued to operate without hard drives with older versions of Flash installed.

Resolution

The AutoZone Store Communications team partnered with a small IT web development team to find a store intranet solution that could be initiated by IT and administered by Store Communications. There was also considerable interest in finding a scalable solution that could eventually be used throughout the company. Given the hardware limitations that existed then and which continue today
column36:
very few appropriate solutions were available to choose from – most required significant overhead to run and significant IT or consulting oversight.

After looking at several possibilities
column37: the team chose the Liferay portal for its flexibility
column38: ease of use and scalability. Liferay portal met all of the team’s requirements and
column39: from the first installation
column40: performed exactly as intended. In fact
column41: the solution exceeded the company’s performance expectations in its ease of administration
column42: straightforward approach to content creation and management
column43: and in the flexibility of authoring and design within the portal templates. The numerous portlets included with Liferay make content and style changes easy and fast
column44:
a real benefit in keeping information fresh and interesting in a fast-moving retail environment.

Today
column45: DOC (Daily Online Communications) is a one-stop communications shop for AutoZone’s 47
column46: 000 store employees. Built using the Liferay portal
column47: DOC has become the one place AutoZoners go to find what they need to know about their weekly tasks
column48: benefits
column49: and training. DOC is also management’s single source for all business reporting. Now positioned for development as AutoZone’s enterprise portal
column50: DOC is streamlining communications
column51: enabling company-wide task management and linking AutoZone’s diverse employee base together in a common community
column52:
furthering strengthening the company’s unique business culture.

]]> '

    <dynamic-content><p align="center"><strong>Liferay Announces Partnership with Triton Services</strong></p> <p>LOS ANGELES
column15: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column16: open source portal and content management system announced a new partnership with Triton Services
column17: Inc. As a Liferay Preferred Partner
column18: Triton will offer Liferay consulting services specific to the unique operational needs of US Government clients such as the Department of Defense (DoD)
column20: State and local agencies and offices.</p> <p>Triton''s expertise and experience in the public sector is an answer to Liferay''s increasing opportunities with government organizations
column22: Liferay''s Chief Exectutive Officer. &ldquo;Triton was already active in our community and is best equipped to deliver Liferay technology to its sector of expertise. For instance
column23: the Triton team is versed in NetCentric Warfare and requirements
column24: processes and protocols of Military clients working within unclassified and classified network environments.</p> <p>In addition to providing services around Liferay Portal
column25: Triton has agreed to contribute all of its research and development around JavaServer Faces (JSF) technology to Liferay''s community
column26: including portlets for accounting
column29: and recruiting. The company has taken a leadership role in the open source realm with regard to testing and debugging ICEfaces
column30: an AJAX-enabled component suite based on JSF technology
column31: within Liferay. By utilizing Liferay and ICEfaces
column32: Triton is building highly responsive rich internet portlets based on AJAX technology.</p> <p>Liferay Portal was already a core part of our ongoing efforts around JSF prior to this partnership
column34: Ray Kwong. &quot;Triton''s goal from the beginning was to fortify Liferay Portal with tools that provide value to government offices trying to ease their IT infrastructure burden. Becoming a Preferred Partner only underscores the cutting-edge work we''ve done with Liferay
column35: and it allows us to serve government clients with Liferay products and services.</p> <p>For more about Liferay Portal
column36: visit www.liferay.com. Additional information about Triton Services can be found at http://www.tritonsvc.com.</p> <p><strong><em>About Liferay:</em></strong></p> <p><em>Liferay Portal is the world''s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column37: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. Liferay clients include Discovery Education
column39: and the Christian Science Monitor. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles. For more information
column40: please visit www.liferay.com.</em></p> <p><strong><em>About Triton:</em></strong></p> <p><em>Headquartered in Bowie
column42: Triton Services
column43: Inc. is a leading engineering services and electron device manufacturing firm specializing in engineering and program management
column47: and other related engineering services. Triton also manufactures a full range of traveling wave tubes
column48: klystrons
column50: microwave power modules and large sunlight readable high definition displays systems for defense and commercial applications.</em></p></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

column12: 'Instructions for how to add a new plugin to the Community Catalog'
column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><h1>Adding a Plugin to the Community Catalog in 3 steps</h1> <p>Liferay allows allow all of it''s community members to register the Themes
column14: Portlets and Layout Templates that they have developed to a community plugin''s catalog. It''s encouraged but not enforced to use an Open Source license
column15: and you can choose to host the plugin files anywhere so Liferay''s catalog will just act as free publicity for your creation.</p> <table cellspacing="3" cellpadding="4" border="0"> <tbody> <tr> <th colspan="2"> <h2>STEP 1 - Create an account in liferay.com and go to <a href="@root_path@/web/guest/downloads/community_plugins">the community catalog</a>.</h2> </th> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p><img src="@root_path@/image/image_gallery?img_id=1755" alt="" /></p> </td> <td valign="top"> <p>&nbsp;</p> <ul> <li>To create an account (if you don''t have one already) use the menu in the upper right corner. Click Sign In
column16: and then go to the Create Account tab. An email will be sent with your password. Use it to log in and accept the ''Terms of use''</li> <ul> <li>Once you are logged in
column17: go to <em>Downloads</em> and then to <em>Community Plugins</em>.</li> </td> </tr> <tr> <th colspan="2"> <h2>STEP 2 - Click the ''Add Product'' button and fill the product details.</h2> </th> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p><img src="@root_path@/image/image_gallery?img_id=1757" alt="" /></p> </td> <td valign="top"> <p>All fields are self explanatory
column18: except for the ones related to the respository:</p> <ul> <li>GroupId: Identifies a group of plugins and serves to avoid namespace conflicts with the product id (aka artifactId). It''s recommended to use the name of your company or institution (i.e. liferay). Another nice convention is to use a domain that you own (i.e. liferay.com).</li> <li>ArtifactId: Identifies this plugin. It should not contain any version information. The artifactId should be unique for a given GroupId.</li> </ul> <p>The combination of id will be used by Liferay to track plugins installed and search for newer versions.</p> <p>Once you''re done click the ''Save'' button.</p> </td> </tr> <tr> <th colspan="2"> <h2>STEP 3 - Within the product view click the ''Add Product Version'' button and fill the form.</h2> </th> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p><img src="@root_path@/image/image_gallery?img_id=1759" alt="" /></p> </td> <td valign="top"> <p>Enter the following details:</p> <ul> <li> Version Name: Should be something such as 4.4.2
column21: etc. Follow a common version pattern so that Liferay''s Plugin Installer can automatically detect new versions when they are available. </li> <li> Changelog: Write a descriptive changelog
column22: including installation and migration instructions </li> <li> Supported Framework versions: Which Liferay versions are supported </li> <li> Download page URL and/or Download URL: it''s recommended to add a direct download URL
column23: that will allow you to add the plugin to the repository. Note that Liferay will NOT host your plugin
column24: you''ll have to upload it somewhere else and provide the download URL. </li> <li> Include Artifact to the Repository: if you set this field to ''Yes'' your plugin will be available to Liferay''s installation through the Plugin Installer. Set it to ''No'' if you only want it available through Liferay''s website </li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <th> <h2>DONE!</h2> </th> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p><img src="@root_path@/image/image_gallery?img_id=1761" alt="" /></p> </td> <td valign="top"> <p>That''s it
column25: now your plugin will be available in Liferay''s website and also visible and installable from the Plugin Installer if you selected ''Yes'' to add it to the repository in the last step.</p> <p>You can repeat this process to add as many themes
column26: portlets and layout templates as you want.</p> <p>From now on you can use the ''My Products'' tab to edit your product and add new versions of it.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h2>RECOMMENDATIONS:</h2> <ul> <li> <p>Include detailed and accurate information.</p> </li> <li> <p>Include screenshots for your plugin</p> </li> <li> <p>For portlets
column27: try to make them auto-installable without a need to reboot. If that''s not possible
column28: please add a warning note in the Changelog for each version of the plugin
column29: telling users to reboot Liferay after installing that plugin.</p> </li> </ul></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

    <dynamic-content><p><strong>Javadocs API</strong></p><p>The following is a list of APIs by subproject. The APIs also include links to the HTML version of the source code.</p> <p>Main modules:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/portal-impl/index.html">PORTAL-IMPL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/portal-kernel/index.html">PORTAL-KERNEL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/portal-service/index.html">PORTAL-SERVICE</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/util-java/index.html">UTIL-JAVA</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/util-taglib/index.html">UTIL-TAGLIB</a></li> </ul><p>Other modules:</p><ul> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/documentlibrary-impl/index.html">DOCUMENTLIBRARY-IMPL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/mail-impl/index.html">MAIL-IMPL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/counter-impl/index.html">COUNTER-IMPL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/lock-impl/index.html">LOCK-IMPL</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/portal-client/index.html">PORTAL-CLIENT</a></li> <li><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.3/api/util-bridges/index.html">UTIL-BRIDGES</a></li> </ul></dynamic-content>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="sidebar-location" type="list">

  <dynamic-element name="sidebar-content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><h2>Training Schedule</h2><p><a href="@root_path@/web/guest/services/training/sydney/course_topics">Course Topics</a></p><h2>Training Time</h2><p>Wed - Fri
column14:
October 10th - 12th<br />9am-5pm daily</p><h2>Course Details</h2><p>3 days Developer Training<br />$2000 USD</p><h2>Location</h2><p>Offices of OpenSoft Australia<br />Level 10 / 221 Miller Street<br />North Sydney</p><h2>Additional Information</h2><p>Please note that a laptop is required for this course.</p><h2>How to Register</h2><p>Email <a href="mailto:sales@liferay.com">sales@liferay.com</a> to register.</p></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="main-content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><h2>Overview</h2><p>Liferay will host a public training seminar October 10th - 12th (Wed-Fri) in Sydney
column15: Australia. Core topics that will be covered include architecture
column17: content management and themes.</p><p>You will learn how to develop using the extension environment
column18: the patterns you need to know to debug through the source code
column19: auto-generation of the service and persistence layer and more.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2>NEW 4.3 Release</h2><p>Come and learn about the new features Liferay Portal 4.3 has to offer!</p><h2>Hands-On Training</h2><p>We will take you through the entire process of portlet development and teach you industry best practices. You will learn how to code the action class
column22: and perform database operations.</p><h2>Subject Matter Experts</h2><p>The course will be led by the Liferay experts who designed the software.</p><h2>Development Environment</h2><p>For development we will setup Tomcat on Eclipse and use MySQL for the database. Although Liferay can be used with any application server and database
column23: the above setup is the fastest in terms of development. We may also touch upon installation with other application servers and databases as well.</p><h2>Prerequisites</h2><p>Basic knowledge of Java and Servlets is required. The course will be intensive
column24: but we will make sure to answer any questions you have to ensure that you have a solid grasp of the technology by the end of the course.</p><p>Please note that a laptop is required for this course.</p><ul><li>Minimum System Requirements: 1.4 GHz 512MB RAM</li><li>Recommended System Requirements: 2.0 GHz 1GB RAM</li><li>Wireless Card Required</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><h2>Contact Us</h2><p>Email us at <a href="mailto:sales@liferay.com">sales@liferay.com</a> to register or if you have any questions.</p></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

    <dynamic-content><p><strong>Sydney
column14: Australia</strong></p> <div> <div class="stct-course-header">Day 1</div> <div class="stct-course-content"> <ul> <li>Introduction to Liferay</li> <li>Installation <ul> <li>Install the Liferay-Tomcat Bundle</li> <li>Install Ant &amp; Jikes</li> <li>Build the EXT (Extension) Environment</li> </ul> </li> <li>Portlet Fundamentals <ul> <li>Overview of JSR 168 (Portlet Specification)</li> <li>JSP Portlet</li> </ul> </li> <li>Portlet MVC (Model View Controller) <ul> <li>Overview of Struts</li> <li>Struts Portlet</li> <li>Overview of the Portlet Lifecycle</li> <li>Add the Controller</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="stct-course-header">Day 2</div> <div class="stct-course-content"> <ul> <li>Configure Liferay to Use a MySQL Database</li> <li>Install Eclipse <ul> <li>Leverage Eclipse to Speed Up Development</li> <li>Debug Java Classes Using Eclipse</li> </ul> </li> <li>Create and Retrieve Records from the Database <ul> <li>Auto-generate the Service and Persistence Layer</li> <li>Implement Business Logic</li> <li>Validate Input</li> </ul> </li> <li>Overview of Permissions <ul> <li>Integrate Permissions into the Struts Portlet</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="stct-course-header">Day 3</div> <div class="stct-course-content"> <ul> <li>Modular Development <ul> <li>JSF Portlet WAR <ul> <li>JSF Overview</li> <li>Backing Beans and UI Components</li> <li>Validation and Messages</li> <li>Navigation and Event Listeners</li> <li>Accessing Liferay Services From a WAR</li> <li>Message Bundles</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Portal Administration</li> <li>CMS - How to Build a Website on Top of the Portal <ul> <li>Using the Journal Content Portlet to Add an Article</li> <li>Adding Portlets to Your Website Using the the Portal</li> </ul> </li> <li>Create a Theme <ul> <li>Configuring Properties</li> <li>Editing the Templates</li> <li>Editing the CSS</li> <li>Adding JavaScript Functions</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </div> </div></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">LIFERAY AND TERRACOTTA PARTNER TO PROVIDE COST-EFFECTIVE HIGH AVAILABILITY FOR THE ENTERPRISE</span><br /><span style="font-style: italic;">World&rsquo;s Most Widely Used Portal Framework to Bundle Terracotta&rsquo;s Leading Infrastructure Software</span></div><p><br />&nbsp;<br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">LOS ANGELES</span> &ndash; (October 1
column16: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class open source portal
column18: a leader in infrastructure software for enterprise Java high availability and scalability
column19: today announced a partnership to respond to growing global demand for the Liferay Portal feature set combined with the scalability and high availability provided by Terracotta. In addition to technical integration
column20: Liferay will bundle Terracotta and serve as a reseller of support.<br /><br />Terracotta offers IT organizations a lightweight approach to scalability that lowers costs and simplifies deployment by reducing development effort and easing the load on application servers and databases.&nbsp; Terracotta uses high-performance mapping of server memory changes
column22: to share temporary &ldquo;work-in-progress&rdquo; data among servers. That makes an application highly available without placing such temporary data in an expensive relational database. It also provides dramatic cost savings and much higher performance and scalability than either databases or application-tier caches.<br />&nbsp;<br />&ldquo;Terracotta takes a smart approach to scalability that works well with Liferay Portal
column24: Liferay&rsquo;s chief executive officer. &ldquo;Our enterprise users will be pleased with how easily Terracotta enhances their most performance-critical Liferay deployments.&rdquo;<br /><br />In its eighth year of development
column25: the award-winning Liferay Portal is chosen by enterprises around the world for its enterprise feature set
column26: flexible architecture
column28: and built-in collaboration and content management capabilities. Liferay Portal boasts a large worldwide community with an average of 40
column29: 000 downloads per month.<br /><br />&ldquo;We are choosing our partnerships very carefully
column31: Terracotta&rsquo;s vice president of product operations. &ldquo;Liferay is the world&rsquo;s most widely used portal framework
column32: &nbsp; and Terracotta is quickly growing in popularity as the Java scalability solution of choice. We look forward to further strengthening our relationship with Liferay as both communities continue their rapid growth.&rdquo;<br /><br />Scalability is becoming a crucial consideration for portal frameworks because of the growing prominence of enterprise portals as a critical component of enterprise SOA initiatives
column33: Liferay has earned industry recognition as a robust enterprise portal solution
column34: and its integration with Terracotta further increases Liferay Portal&rsquo;s value proposition to the enterprise market.<br /><br />For more information and an online demo
column35: visit www.liferay.com.<br /><br /><br style="font-weight: bold;" /><span style="font-weight: bold;">About Liferay Inc.</span><br />Liferay
column36: Inc. is the provider of Liferay Portal
column37: the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients world-wide. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column38: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles.&nbsp; For more information
column39: please visit www.liferay.com<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">About Terracotta
column40: Inc.</span><br />Terracotta&rsquo;s infrastructure software provides affordable and scalable high availability for Java applications. Companies use Terracotta to offload work from databases and application servers and to reduce their development efforts. Founded in 2003
column42: Inc.
column43: is a private firm headquartered in San Francisco. More information is available at www.terracottatech.com. Terracotta&rsquo;s open source community is available at www.terracotta.org.<br /><br />&nbsp;<br /><br />----<br />&nbsp;<br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">PRESS CONTACTS:</span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />Corey Gutwillig&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />S&amp;S Public Relations
column44: Inc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />847/955-0700 ext. 9333<br />cgutwillig@sspr.com&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br /><br />Amy Burnis or John McElhenny

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><div style="text-align: center;"><font size="3"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Liferay Expands to China</span></font><br /><span style="font-style: italic;">Company Opens Dalian Office</span><br style="font-style: italic;" /><span style="font-style: italic;">In Response to Rapid Growth</span></div><p><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">DALIAN
column17: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column18: open source portal and content management system
column19: today announced the opening of a new Asian&nbsp; headquarters in Dalian
column20: China. The new office and local staff supports rapid company growth and product demand.&nbsp;&nbsp; <br /><br />&ldquo;By tapping into a rich local talent pool
column21: the Dalian office not only serves to support worldwide product development
column22: but also helps to foster a rich technology exchange
column24: Liferay&rsquo;s CEO. &ldquo;The open source software movement is growing at a phenomenal rate in China. Liferay aims to help foster and expand it.&rdquo;<br /><br />Located in the Dalian Hi-tech Industrial Zone
column25: Liferay&rsquo;s new office joins many other global IT firms in leveraging access to Dalian&rsquo;s regional technical universities and an IT-savvy workforce. The Industrial Zone was one of the first state-level hi-tech zones approved by the state council and has been home to IT mainstays such as Accenture
column26: HP and IBM for several years. <br /><br />&ldquo;Establishing a local presence will also give us access to new business opportunities&mdash;not just in China
column28: South Korea and Japan as well
column29: &rdquo; continued Cheung. &ldquo;Our office is headed up by members of our US team who have the requisite experience and knowledge to lead local talent and spearhead business opportunities in the long-term.&rdquo;&nbsp; Liferay is also leveraging the local business expertise of local technology firm
column31: in the areas of talent selection and staffing.<br /><br />Liferay Portal
column32: Liferay&rsquo;s flagship open source product
column33: enjoys immense popularity around the world averaging roughly 40
column35: more than any other java-based portal in the open source realm. A significant portion of this traffic is from China
column36: where the market has shown impressive adoption of open source software and where an independently formed Liferay User Group already meets on a monthly basis in Beijing. Within enterprises
column37: the product is being chosen for its intuitive UI
column39: strong support for standards
column40: and robust internationalization features. <br /><br />For more information about Liferay Dalian or Liferay Portal
column41: contact pr@liferay.com or visit www.liferay.com.<br /><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">About Liferay:</span><br />Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients around the world. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column42: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles with regional headquarters in Germany and China. For more information
column43: please visit www.liferay.com.</p><div style="text-align: center;"># # # #&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><p><br /><span style="font-weight: bold;">PRESS CONTACT:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />Corey Gutwillig&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />S&amp;S Public Relations

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1774&t=1201070919219 W-JAX 2007
November 5-9
column15:
Germany

 

W-JAX is the number one conference for Java
column16: enterprise architecture and SOA. W-JAX offers expert level technical information for project managers
column20:
keynotes and idea exchange form the basis of this annual event.

Liferay will be presenting and exhibiting at JAX DE as a Preferred Partner:

 

Gadgets
column23:
Social Networking: A developer’s perspective
Jorge Ferrer

With all the hype around gadgets
column25: social networks and Web 2.0
column26: it''s tempting to think that portals have outlived their usefulness as ways to connect people with applications
column28: and other people. But enterprises wanting to leverage the benefits of collaborative web applications will find a natural place for them in the portal
column29: which is evolving beyond a simple content aggregator to a complete suite of collaboration and content management tools and a platform for deploying applications. Portals can also take advantage of massive communities like Facebook by bridging the gap between various technologies through the resiliency of the Java platform. We''ll demonstrate how remotely hosted applications (written in Java
column30:
PHP or Ruby) can be quickly deployed over the network.

]]>\n \n'

January 22–24
column14:
2008
Nuremberg Germany

Liferay is a partner for this event. A number of our customers will be presenting their portal projects and case studies of their business pain points and Liferay Portal''s value. CEO
column15: Bryan Cheung will be presenting a keynote entitled
column18:
and Web 2.0 for the Enterprise"

Open Source Meets Business is a congress for CIOs
column20: and IT decision makers. As Open Source is gaining importance
column21: the conference analyzes this trend by addressing decision makers from user companies
column23:
as well as from the financial community.

  • Deploying Open Source in the Enterprise (Enterprise Summit): IT managers from companies of all industries and sizes describe their experience in OS software deployment in mission-critical applications.
  • Open Source projects and their business perspectives (Technology Summit): Internationally renowned heads of the Open Source marketplace introduce status and roadmaps of the most important projects and discuss their visions of the future.
  • Open Source meets Money (Investment Summit): Forward-looking investors reveal how they act in the Open Source marketplace. Interesting start ups and companies on a growth path present their concepts and ideas.

 

]]>\n \n'

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><h2 align="right"><font size="5"><em>One click install</em></font></h2> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><strong>What is the Liferay Software Repository?</strong></p> <p>Our <em>Software Repository </em>is an exclusive feature of Liferay Portal that allows administrators to install
column17: all online with one click.</p> <p><strong>What is a Plugin?</strong></p> <p>Plugins are ready-made additions to your basic Liferay Portal. These can be extra portlets
column18: new themes or layouts.</p> <p>The repository keeps track of version numbers and compatibility issues (for example
column19: a portlet may only be compatible on Liferay 4.3.1) to reduce administration headaches.</p> <p>By communicating with remote servers
column20: the Software Repository discovers new functionality and content available both from Liferay and from third party portlet
column22: thereby creating an online community of offerings.</p> <p>And with instant
column24: </em> the process is effortless.</p> <p><br /> <strong>Why is the Liferay Software </strong><strong>Repository </strong><strong>Significant?<br /> </strong></p> <p>The development cycle for software is getting shorter and shorter
column25: and Web 2.0 properties in particular are in a state of &quot;perpetual beta.&quot; The ability to quickly deploy new features into a production environment is key to a company or website staying competitive and attracting a critical mass of community members
column26: the key competitive advantage of any social network.</p> <p>The Software Repository ensures that the latest developments are available to our clients'' platforms. More importantly
column27: it keeps the management of those features as painless as possible.</p> <p>We offer 2 categories of Plugins in the Software Repository:</p> <blockquote> <ul> <li><strong><a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/downloads/official_plugins">Official Plugins</a></strong> - These are contributed by Liferay and authorized Liferay partners. They are verified by Liferay as trusted plugins.</li> <li><strong><a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/downloads/community_plugins">Community Plugins</a></strong> - These are contributed by our community. Anyone can submit their own plugins. A 3-step guide will guide you through the process.</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p></blockquote><p>Bookmark the pages

column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><div align="center"><p><font size="3"><strong>Liferay and Pentaho Announce Technology Partnership</strong></font></p><p>&nbsp;</p></div> <p><strong> Orlando
column16: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column17: open source portal and content management system and Pentaho Corp.
column18: creator of the world&rsquo;s most popular open source business intelligence (BI) suite
column19: today announced a technology partnership to enhance integration between their product lines. By working together
column20: Liferay and Pentaho will leverage open standards to simplify deployment for enterprise organizations looking to leverage commercial open source software to securely enable access to BI content as part of an overall enterprise portal strategy.</p> <p>Portals provide an ideal framework to seamlessly integrate business intelligence with other enterprise applications and content. An enterprise portal framework makes it easy to deliver the benefits of business intelligence to large numbers of users
column21: while enhancing the value of BI with application context
column23: and an intuitive multi-application user interface. Portals can also make it easy for users to create personalized views of information
column24: including dashboards that integrate BI with other enterprise content.</p> <p>&ldquo;Integrating business intelligence with enterprise portal frameworks provides a great opportunity to deliver greater information value to larger user communities
column25: &rdquo; said Mark Smith
column26: CEO and EVP of Research at Ventana Research. &ldquo;Liferay and Pentaho are expanding the access and attractiveness of their products to the enterprise by providing simplified configuration and tighter integration.&rdquo;</p> <p>Pentaho and Liferay both support the JSR-168 portal integration standard
column28: standards-based method for integration. The companies are planning to work together to make integrated deployment even easier with minimal customization and configuration effort. The next phase of integration is expected to be delivered in Q1 of 2008.</p> <p><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong><br />Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients around the world. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column29: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles with regional headquarters in Germany and China. For more information
column30: please visit www.liferay.com.</em></p><p><em><strong>About Pentaho Corporation:</strong><br />Pentaho Corporation provides a full spectrum of open source Business Intelligence (BI) capabilities including reporting
column31: analysis
column32: dashboards
column35: and a BI platform that have made it the world&rsquo;s most popular open source BI suite. Formed by a highly experienced team of industry veterans
column36: Pentaho&rsquo;s mission is to bring innovative
column37: high quality technology and professional support to the BI market. Pentaho uses a revolutionary approach to development
column38: distribution and support made possible by a commercial open source business model. Pentaho is the primary sponsor and owner of popular open source projects including JFreeReport
column39: Kettle
column40: Mondrian
column41: and Weka. Pentaho&rsquo;s technologies support a wide range of business initiatives from sales and profitability analysis
column42: customer analysis
column43: HR reporting
column47: and operational reporting. For more information
column48: visit www.pentaho.com</em></p><div align="center"><em>----</em></div><p><strong>Press Contact: </strong><br />Corey Gutwillig <br />S&amp;S Public Relations

column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
	<dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
		<dynamic-content><p>A great product can only improve with the expertise of the larger community.&nbsp;</p> <p>Liferay Portal&nbsp;is a free open source project that is being continuously improved and extended by one of the most mature and active open source communities in the portal space. We average 40
column14: 000 downloads per month and count over 1 million downloads!</p> <p>These pages will provide you with a built-in product support system and developer network. Here
column15: you will find detailed documentation on key features of Liferay. You can explore and participate in our forums for community support if you run into questions. You can also&nbsp;contribute to Liferay Portal''s ongoing evolution by&nbsp;submitting bug reports
column17: and code contributions on our support site.</p> <p>Contact us via the forums if you have any questions
column18: comments or qualms!</p> <ul> <li>The Liferay Team</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>PS: Check out our new <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/community/blog" target="_blank">blogs</a>!</p><p><table width="100%" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="1" border="0" align="center"><tbody><tr><td><a target="_blank" href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Liferay_Community_Roadmap">Liferay Community Roadmap</a></td><td><a target="_blank" href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/How_to_contribute_to_Liferay">How to Contibute</a></td><td>&nbsp;</td><td>&nbsp;</td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr></tbody></table></p><p>&nbsp;</p></dynamic-content>\n	</dynamic-element>\n</root>'

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><h2>Installation and Upgrade Instructions</h2> <p>Information about the installation options

column13:
' Enterprise Architecture
  • Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) - Liferay uses SOA design principles throughout and provides the tools and framework to extend SOA to other enterprise applications.
    • The ServiceMix enterprise service bus (ESB) is a central connection manager that allows applications and services to be added quickly to an enterprise’s infrastructure. When an application needs to be replaced
column14:
it can be easily disconnected from the bus at a single point. Other open source ESBs such as Mule can also be plugged in.
  • Support for Web Services makes it easy for different applications in your enterprise to communicate with each other. Java
column16:
and proprietary applications can work together easily because Web Services use XML standards.
  • Support for REST-style JSON Web Services for lightweight
column17:
maintainable code and to support AJAX-based user interfaces.
  • Security – Liferay uses industry standard
column18: government-grade encryption technologies including advanced algorithms such as DES
column19:
MD5 and RSA. Liferay was benchmarked as among the most secure portal platforms using LogicLibrary''s Logiscan suite.
  • Single Sign On – Liferay offers customizable single sign-on with Yale CAS
column24:
and more. Yale CAS integration is offered out of the box.
  • Multi-Tier
column25: Limitless Clustering – Cluster Liferay Portal Enterprise at any combination of multiple tiers – presentation
column26: service
column28: and database – to meet your specific load requirements
column29:
one processor at a time. Liferay has also been deployed to Amazon EC2 which uses virtualization and cloud computing technologies to scale dynamically to geographically specific areas of demand.
  • High Availability – Maintain zero down time for business critical applications with Hardware/Software Load Balancing
column31: Session Replication
column32:
and Distributed Cache (using Lightweight Multicast Protocol).
  • Page Caching – Increase web performance with full-page caching for static content.
  • Dynamic Virtual Hosting – Granting individual community members their own page with a user-defined friendly URL.

More information...

  • Portlet API
  • Struts & Tiles
  • Spring & Hibernate
  • SOAP

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><h2>Liferay 4.3 - Spurgeon <p>NEW FEATURES</p></h2> <p>Take a look at some of the new features of 4.3.x. All links direct you to the Liferay Wiki definition of the respective feature with additional technical information. If you would like additional information about any of the new features
column14: please email <a href="mailto:product-mgt@liferay.com?subject=Features%20Inquiry">product-mgt@liferay.com</a>. Thanks again to the community for helping to make this possible!</p> <ul> <li><font color="#ff0000"><strong>The Liferay Team </strong></font></li> </ul> <p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Architecture</strong></p> <ul> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Staging">Portal Publishing &amp; Staging Framework</a></li> <li>Liferay Software Catalog <ul> <li>Provide a plug-in framework to install Liferay components</li> </ul></li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/How_to_use_the_sitemap_protocol_with_Liferay">Sitemaps Protocol Support</a></li> <li>Enterprise Search: OpenSearch Support</li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Exposing_Microformats_in_Liferay">Microformat Support</a></li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Community_Roles">Community-Scoped Roles</a> (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Dynamic_Management_of_Companies">Multiple Enterprise Management
column15: aka Dynamic Company Management</a></li> <li>ICEfaces Integration for AJAX + JSF</li> <li>Deprecate EJB services in favor of Spring POJO''s</li> <li>Tag / Folksonomy and Asset Management Framework (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>Expose REST-style JSON Web Services</li> <li>Javascript Client Libraries for JSON Web Services</li> <li>LAR Import / Export for Themes (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>PHP and Ruby Support</li> </ul> <h2>Security</h2> <ul> <li>Enterprise Password Policy Management w / Provisioning to LDAP (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>Active Directory Single-SignOn via NTLM</li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Using_OpenID_with_Liferay">OpenID Enabled SSO</a></li> </ul> <h2>Performance improvements</h2> <ul> <li>Database tuning</li> <li>Scalability - optimize memory usage</li> </ul> <h2>Integration</h2> <ul> <li>Microsoft Exchange <ul> <li>iCal Support - Import\Export from Calendar Portlet</li> </ul></li> <li>Yahoo Maps</li> <li>Full WebDAV Support</li> </ul> <h2>Context-Sensitive Help</h2> <h2>Liferay Eclipse</h2> <ul> <li>Portlet Development</li> <li>Portlet Deployment</li> </ul> <h2>Portlets</h2> <ul><li>Tags Admin (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>Tags Content (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>Tagify Existing Portlets (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>PHP and Ruby Sample Portlets</li> <li>Sample ICEfaces Portlet</li> </ul> <h2>Themes/Layout</h2> <ul> <li>Role-base Theme Management (Sponsored Feature)</li> <li>Standardize on jQuery JavaScript Framework</li> <li>Simplify Theme Development Process&nbsp; <ul> <li>Semantic and Non-Obtrusive Markup</li> <li>Standards Compliance</li> </ul></li> <li>Free-form (WebOS) Layout</li> <li><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Page_link_to_another_page">Link to Layout Type</a></li> <li><a target="_blank" href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/WAP_Mobile_Device_Themes_with_Liferay">Mobile Device Support</a> (Sponsored Feature)</li> </ul></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><div class="release-process-container"><p>We plan to release new versions of Liferay at 3-4 month intervals -- roughly 3-4 releases every year. Our philosophy has always been to release early and often.</p> <p>During our development cycle for a particular release
column14: we are always forward-looking at the following two releases down the road. Every release is different. We may plan to focus on new functionality in one release
column16: or purely on backend features and developer tools. Mostly likely there will be advancements at some level on all fronts.</p> <p>Although our intention is to release every three to four months
column17: exact dates need to be set on a release by release basis. Depending on community and customer-driven features and contributions
column18: these dates are subject to change.</p> <p>The following describes our release schedule:</p> <h2>Early Access Releases (i.e. liferay-portal-a.b-EAn)</h2> <p>When the development team reaches certain milestones
column19: we may decide to make a number of early access (EA) releases. The intention for these releases is to allow the Liferay commnunity to test drive key new functionality and have an opportunity to provide valuable feedback before the features are finalized. We will provide minimal packaging for the EA releases -- Tomcat bundle and source code.</p> <h2>Feature Freeze</h2> <p>No new functionality will be introduced after this point. Only bug fixes are allowed to be committed to SVN. At this time a branch is made off SVN trunk for the new release. This is the branch where all releases related to this particular version are made (Release Candidates
column22: if we are planning to release version a.b
column23: we will create a branch named /branches/a.b.x in SVN.</p> <h2>Stabilization and Release Candidates (i.e. liferay-portal-a.b-RCn)</h2> <p>During this time period we will be working to stablize the upcoming release. When a substantial number of issues have been addressed and gone through our QA process
column24: we will make a release candidate available. During this phase a number of release candidates will be made
column25: and when all serious issues have been addressed
column26: the final release -- Generally Available (GA) release will be made. We will provide full packaging for RC releases (app servers
column31: fully packaged
column32: officially supported release.</p> <h2>Maintenance Releases (i.e liferay-portal-a.b.c-GA)</h2> <p>A bug fix release. Any bugs found after the final release will be addressed by any number of maintenance releases. We will be implementing process this following our 4.3 release.</p></div></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'
column39: 'Joe Bloggs'

This gives Discussion Services administrators full control over who can access what content using either interface approach. <root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p><strong>Introduction </strong><br />There are several ways in which you can help Liferay depending on your capabilities. Some examples are: <br /><br />Write documentation of some feature that you know in the wiki <br />Test it and file the bugs you find <br />Implement a new feature or extend the existing ones <br />Suggest a new feature <br />The next section gives more information about each of these <br /><br />[edit]Write documentation <br />Liferay has both an official documentation and a community based documentation created through a wiki (right were this page is in). <br /><br />If you feel that the are some details that need documentation or you feel that some of the existing documentation use this wiki. Here are specific instructions on what you can do here: <br /><br />How to Request an article <br />How to Improve an article <br />How to Create a new article <br /><br />For more information go to the LiferayPedia:Community Portal <br /><br />[edit]Contribute with new features <br />Make sure the feature does not exist <br />Comment the feature in the message boards to let other people give their opinion about it <br />Download Liferay''s latest sources and make the changes there <br />Go to the support website and add an issue explaining your feature <br />Create a patch for your changes and upload it as an attachment to the issue you created <br />It must always be done against latest trunk (specify the revision in the patch comment) <br />The patch should be created with the patch utility to include only differences <br />Don''t include differences for files that are generated with ServiceBuilder <br />Once you are done click &quot;Resolve issue&quot;. Do not &quot;close it&quot;
column14: just &quot;resolve it&quot;. <br />Some tips: <br /><br />It''s much easier for Liferay''s developers to receive several small patches than a huge one
column15: because the latter takes more time to review. <br />Follow the conventions of the existing code as strictly as you can: pay atention to class names
column16: variable names and all the coding style. <br />[edit]Notify a bug <br />Make sure it really is a bug <br />Post the problem in the message boards <br />Go to the support website and add an issue explaining the bug <br />Try to explain the way Liferay works and the way it should work in a very detailed way. <br />If you have the knowledge create a patch that solves the bug <br />[edit]Suggest a new feature <br />Go to the message boards and suggest the feature <br />If the community likes it
column17: once it''s defined it will be added to this wiki under the Proposed Projects page. <br />Retrieved from &quot;http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/How_to_contribute_to_Liferay&quot;</p></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

and operating systems (over 700 deployment combinations)

  • Award winning AJAX enabled user interface

' Features

Liferay Journal is Liferay Portal''s built-in content management system (CMS) ready to deliver portal-based web publishing and document management. A good content management system can significantly reduce the operating cost of publishing
column15:
and maintaining web content and document libraries. Minimize the cost and complexity of enterprise content management with this out of the box portlet suite.

  • Web Publishing - Liferay Journal''s web publishing system can be used to quickly create web pages using re-usable content
column17:
and dynamically generated site taxonomy. Templates can be written using Velocity or XSLT.
  • Flexible Templating Mechanism (XSL/VM) - Templates used for creating articles can be created in either XSL or Velocity (VM)
column18:
giving developers flexibility in designing their websites.
  • Document Library - The Document Library provides a centralized repository with versioning and library services (check in/check out) backed by a JCR-170 compliant Java Content Repository (Jackrabbit) for various documents (e.g.
column22: etc.) to be stored and given a unique URL.  A company''s intranet running Liferay Portal can then be able to post internal documentation used for employees.  Alternatively
column23: since each document has its own URL
column24:
a portlet on your company''s public website can reference any of the documents stored there as well.
  • Image Gallery - Like the Document Library
column25: the Image Gallery provides a central repository for images used throughout the Liferay Portal by a unique URL.  A company can add images
column26: reference them in the portal
column27:
and view all your images through a slideshow.
  • Portal Publishing & Staging - Edit content on a live page of your website without changing what the public sees until you’re ready. Staging allows for multiple working copies of the same page at any given time and previews them without disrupting the actual live pages.
  • Sitemaps Protocol Support - Enhance your organization’s marketing efforts by instantaneously making any new pages searcheable by the major search engines. Liferay has out of the box support for automatically updating sitemap information available for web-crawling.
  • Federated Search - Liferay Portal leverages Amazon’s OpenSearch to return federated search results from multiple content sources including Liferay portlets and external integrated applications.
  • Meta Tags - Liferay’s new tagging system allows you to tag web content
column30:
and dynamically publish content by tags.
  • Structured Content - Liferay Journal segregates the creation of content between designer and writer.  Less technical persons can create web content using one of the built-in WYSIWGs (What You See Is What You Get editors) without sifting through complex code. Assign a web designer to layout the data without having to come up with content.  Liferay Journal divides the process into three different areas: structures
column31: templates
column32:
and articles.

 

See Full Portlet List

]]>\n \n'

	</dynamic-element>
	<dynamic-element name="page-description" type="text">
		<dynamic-content><![CDATA[]]></dynamic-content>
	</dynamic-element>
</root>'

' Liferay Portal offers unbeatable out-of-the-box functionality with over 60 JSR-168 compliant portlets:

Portlet Category

  • Administration
  • Content Management
  • Collaboration
  • Community
  • Entertainment
  • Personal Tools
  • Shopping Tools
  • Developer Tools

 

See Full Portlet List

Administration

Admin Portlet

Shows Liferay Portal version information
column25:
and more.

Enterprise Admin Portlet

Allows users (with permissions) to manage users
column26: organizations
column30:
and to set their permissions.

Page Settings

Liferay also has a Page Settings configuration area that can be used to change look and feel with one click
column31: manage portal pages
column32: insert Javascript and meta-data
column33:
and set friendly URLs.

Content Management

Alfresco Content

Provides integration into Alfresco ECM
column34:
including:

  • Integrated Browsing and Publishing of HTML Content
  • Inline-Editing of Content (Requires SSO)
  • Images and Content Contained and Displayed within the Portal
  • Workflow and Preview of Unpublished Content

 

Document Library

Provides document management backed by the Jackrabbit JSR-170 compliant Java content repository. Includes check in / check out
column36:
and versioning.

Journal

Main interface for Liferay’s integrated web publishing system. Allows users to create
column39: as well as article templates for one click changes in layout. Journal has built in workflow
column40: article versioning
column42:
and meta-data.

Journal Articles

Displays a dynamic list of all Journal articles for a given Community. List can include the top articles by creation date
column43: publication date
column45:
or other criteria and will automatically update when new articles are added to the CMS.

Journal Content

This portlet can be used to publish any article from the Journal CMS on a portal page. Journal Content portlets comprise most of the content on Liferay.com and other Liferay-driven websites
column46:
and can be arranged on a page with the convenient drag and drop feature of Liferay.

Journal Content Search

A search restricted to the content of Journal CMS articles. Powered by the Apache Lucene search engine.

Recent Documents

Displays articles most recently added to the Document Library.

Breadcrumb

Displays a trail of “parent” pages for the current page. The Breadcrumb Portlet can be placed on public portal pages as a navigational aid when using Liferay to publish websites.

Navigation

Provides a directory of links reflecting the portal’s page structure
column47: with drill down into the current page. Style and appearance can be adjusted. Unlike the Breadcrumb Portlet
column48:
the Navigation Portlet displays links for other pages outside of the current page’s trail of “parent” pages.

Site Map

Displays a structured directory of links to all pages in the portal. The Site Map can be used to navigate directly to any page on the site. It can be configured to display the entire site or a sub-section of pages.

Collaboration

Blogs

A basic blogging portlet that includes categories
column50:
and publication date.

Calendar

A portlet that displays calendar information and allows users to create
column52: and search for events. Events can be shared across communities
column53: and event reminders can be set up to alert users of upcoming events by email
column55:
or SMS.

Enterprise Instant Messaging

An AJAX Enterprise Instant Messaging client that allows users to automatically chat over Jabber protocol with other logged-in portal users. Chat sessions are persisted across portal pages and as secure as other portal functionality.

Mail

An AJAX webmail client that can be configured to work with any mail server. Liferay Mail displays message lists and message previews in a dual pane window to reduce page refreshes. Messages can be searched or sorted by different criteria to find messages quickly. Drag and drop makes it easy to organize and delete messages.

Message Boards

A full-featured forums solution with threaded views
column62:
and forum statistics. Message Boards work with Liferay’s fine-grained permissions to give detailed levels of control to administrators and users.

Wiki

A straightforward Wiki solution with categories; Classic Wiki
column64:
or plain text modes; WYSIWYG editing; page history and reversion; and permissions.

Community

Announcements

Offers a free form text area that can display and update new information quickly. The Announcements Portlet is visible to all page visitors.

Bookmarks

A simple way for users to keep track of URLs in the portal. The Bookmarks Portlet can also be used by an administrator to publish relevant links to a group of users.

Communities

Used to create and manage new portal communities and their users. A community in Liferay is like a separate portal instance; each community gets its own set of pages
column68:
a user belonging to multiple communities can navigate among them within the same portal session.

Directory

A listing of all users registered on the portal. The Directory Portlet displays personal information for individual users and also gives listings of available organizations
column70:
and user groups.

Polls

The Polls Portlet allows users or administrators to create multiple choice polls that keep track of votes and display results on the page. Many separate polls can be managed; a separate portlet can be configured to display a specific poll’s results.

Entertainment

Games

Includes a campy rendition of Hangman and the Windows classic
column71:
Minesweeper.

Reverend Fun

A daily comic panel.

Words

Shows lists of words that can be formed from the letters of any input.

Personal Tools

Financial Tools

  • A basic Calculator
  • Personalizable Stock Quotes
  • Loan / Mortgage Payment Calculator
  • Currency Converter

Google Portlets

These include:

  • Google Search Portlet
  • Google AdSense for displaying ad content
  • Google Gadget for publishing Google’s widgets to Liferay Portal
  • Google Maps Portlet to facilitate mashup creation and show customized driving directions and locations.

 

News and RSS

The News and RSS Portlets allows users to get dynamically updated digests of critical news topics
column73:
and other publications. Users can configure the order of topics displayed and how many articles are shown per provider.

Weather

A simple weather portlet can display current conditions for as many cities as desired and also gives a quick interface to looking up detailed weather information by city or zip code.

Other Tools

Other Personal Tools include an Analog Clock
column82:
Translator and Unit Converter.

Religion Portlets

Several portlets dealing with religious or spiritual topics are available and can be used as prototypes for other similar portlets. These include a scripture reference tool
column83: a guide to prayer for current world events
column84: and a daily historical events portlet
column85:
among others.

Shopping Tools

Amazon Rankings

This portlet uses the Amazon API to display Amazon sales information on any number of items added by the user. It can be used as a prototype for using to API to mash up Amazon data with other proprietary data or web services.

Shopping

The Shopping Portlet offers inventory management including SKU
column93:
checkout with credit card payments and more.

Developer Tools

Prototype Portlets

Several Prototype Portlets ship with Liferay to provide examples of how to incorporate other technologies with Liferay at the presentation layer. These include Flash
column99:
and Web Proxy.

 

WSRP

The WSRP Proxy Portlet allows users to access portlets published by other portals across the Internet using Web Services.

Workflow

The Workflow Portlet lets users manage workflows from the presentation layer. Future versions will allow users to create and edit workflows using a simple drag and drop style interface.

]]>\n \n'

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><table class="tech-spec-table"> <tbody> <tr> <td class="tech-spec-cat">Application Servers<br /> <br /> Databases<br /> <br /> Operating Systems</td> <td><p>Liferay supports ALL major app servers
column15: and operating systems with over 700 deployment configurations.</p> <p>Please see our <a href="@root_path@/web/guest/products/tech_specs/deployment_matrix">deployment matrix</a> for more details.</p></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="tech-spec-cat">Languages</td> <td><p>Liferay supports I18N for any language out-of-the-box and ships with default translations for 22 languages. Additional languages can be <a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Translating_Liferay_to_a_New_Language">added</a> very easily.</p> <table class="no-borders"> <tbody> <tr> <td><ul> <li>Arabic</li> <li>Catalan (Spain)</li> <li>Chinese (Simplified)</li> <li>Chinese (Traditional)</li> <li>Czech</li> <li>Dutch</li> <li>English (US)</li> <li>Finnish</li> <li>French</li> <li>German</li> <li>Greek</li> </ul></td> <td><ul> <li>Hungarian</li> <li>Italian</li> <li>Japanese</li> <li>Korean</li> <li>Persian</li> <li>Portuguese</li> <li>Russian</li> <li>Spanish</li> <li>Swedish</li> <li>Turkish</li> <li>Vietnamese</li> </ul></td> </tr> </tbody> </table></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="tech-spec-cat">Supported Technologies</td> <td valign="top"><table class="no-borders"> <tbody> <tr> <td><p><a href="@root_path@/web/guest/products/tech_specs/tech_used">Technologies Used:</a></p> <ul> <li>Apache ServiceMix</li> <li>ehcache</li> <li>Hibernate</li> <li>ICEfaces</li><li>Java J2EE/JEE</li> <li>jBPM</li><li>JGroups</li><li>jQuery JavaScript Framework</li> <li>Lucene</li> <li>MuleSource ESB</li> <li>PHP</li> <li>Ruby</li> <li>Seam</li> <li>Spring &amp; AOP</li> <li>Struts &amp; Tiles</li> <li>Tapestry</li> <li>Velocity</li> </ul></td> <td><p><a href="@root_path@/web/guest/products/tech_specs/standards">Standards:</a></p> <ul> <li>AJAX</li> <li>iCalendar &amp; Microformat</li> <li>JSR-168</li> <li>JSR-127</li> <li>JSR-170</li> <li>Seats on the JSR-286 (Portlet 2.0) and JSF-314 (JSF 2.0) committees</li> <li>OpenSearch</li> <li>Open platform with support for web services including: <ul> <li>JSON</li> <li>Hessian</li> <li>Burlap</li> <li>REST</li> <li>RMI</li> <li>WSRP</li> </ul></li> <li>WebDAV</li> </ul></td> </tr> </tbody> </table></td> </tr> </tbody> </table></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

column13:
' Enterprise Performance in the Lab and the Real World

Performance and scalability are essential to the successful deployment of an enterprise portal application. Liferay Portal has performed well in high-traffic
column14:
heavy-usage deployments in real world applications worldwide.

\n

Liferay has also exhibited impressive results in lab-based stress tests engineered both by independent testers and our internal development team. In a recent
column19: a J2EE stack built on CentOS Linux
column21: and Liferay (labelled "Linux J2EE in comparison charts) was measured as delivering the <a href="http://www.eweek.com/slideshow_viewer/0
column25: the second <a href="http://www.eweek.com/slideshow_viewer/0
column32:
00.asp">highest average document download time among eight different portal solutions.

\n

On the
column39: Liferay outperformed JBoss Portal by a whopping factor of 23. On the <a href="http://www.eweek.com/slideshow_viewer/0
column42: 00.asp">throughput metric
column43: Liferay significantly outperformed all other configurations except .NET
column44:
by an average factor of 10.

\n

Liferay Portal has also been certified by Azul Systems on its 384 CPU environment
column45:
demonstrating its scalability in a highly-clustered environment.

\n

For our internal benchmarks of Liferay Portal
column46: we used Microsoft''s Web Application Stress Tool (WAST). The primary goal of the load tests was to determine the page load time of a 3400+ Sempron running Liferay under varying amounts of load. The Sempron was chosen to represent a budget server
column47:
to serve as a lower threshold of expected performance (more robust servers should deliver greater performance).

These are the exact specifications of the test components:

Server:

AMD Sempron 3400+
column48:
2 GB RAM running Liferay Portal Professional 4.0.0 (Bundled with Tomcat for JDK 5.0) with the following modifications:

\n
    \n
  • The maximum number of allowable threads was set to 20
column49:
000.
  • The maximum size of the JVM heap was set to 1280.

    • Client Machines:

    (6) AMD 3400+ Sempron(s) with 2 GB RAM running Microsoft Web Application Stress Tool

    Understanding the Test

    Our tests dealt simply with threads from the client machines making requests to the server. In the absence of a true high volume of concurrent users
column50: or of user emulation that accurately includes think time
column51:
threadwise performance can be multiplied (by a conservative or aggressive factor) to extrapolate an estimate of how many users can be handled by the server with the given hardware profile. The threadwise performance of the server is an easily comparable metric across test results.

\n

Metrics

\n

The primary metric WAST generates is Total Time until Last Byte is received (TTLB)
column52: commonly understood as page load time. This is an appropriate metric for a web-based application such as a portal
column53:
and is the determining factor of a user’s psychological perception of a site''s performance.

The secondary metric is requests per second. This metric allows one to determine the server’s peak point of operating efficiency. The server should never reach a point where there is a sharp drop in the number of requests per second it can handle.

Results

Liferay Portal supports up to 9
column54: 000 concurrent page requests with a page load time of 6 seconds on a 3400+ Sempron server. Even at 18
column56: page load time only increased by 0.552s. A conservative user multiplier of 5 would yield 45
column57: 000 concurrent users with a page load time of about 6.0 seconds and little or no degradation in operating efficiency. A more aggressive multiplier of 15 would yield an estimate of 135
column58:
000 concurrent users.

\n

Notes on Testing Methodology

\n

Additional client machines were added to create additional load as each previous client''s processor usage of a client machine approached 90%. Above this threshold
column59: clients begin to incorrectly simulate load. In the chart above
column60: additional clients were added every 3000 threads
column61:
which was the point at which the 90% threshold was met.

]]>\n \n'

<root>

    <dynamic-content><![CDATA[Glossary]]></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
</root>'

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><table cellspacing="15" cellpadding="0" boder="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td valign="top"><strong>Term</strong></td> <td width="90%" valign="top"><strong>Definition</strong></td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">CMS</td> <td valign="top">Content Management System. System used to allow the non-technical writer to easily produce and present material on a web page. The CMS technology developed in Liferay is also known as the <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/products/journal">Liferay Journal</a>.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">JSR-168</td> <td valign="top">A Java Community Process (JCP) standard specification for the interoperability between Portlets and Portals. See <a href="http://www.jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=168">spec</a>.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">JSR-170</td> <td valign="top">A Java Community Process (JCP) standard specification for a repository of content used by the CMS. See <a href="http://www.jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=170">spec</a>.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Liferay Journal</td> <td valign="top">Liferay''s CMS <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/products/journal">product</a>.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Liferay Portal Enterprise</td> <td valign="top">JSR-168 portal that supports EJBs. The code is identical with Liferay Portal Professional.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Liferay Portal Professional</td> <td valign="top">JSR-168 portal that does not support EJBs. The code is identical with Liferay Portal Enterprise.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Open Source</td> <td valign="top">Open source software (OSS) is software that is freely shared. The source code is made available for use or modification to users and the developer community at no cost.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Portal</td> <td valign="top">A website that shares information and enables collaboration of its users through the use of its portlets. <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/products/portal/WhatIsAPortal">Read more...</a><br /> Liferay Portal has been used by businesses
column16: and many others. See their <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/stories">stories</a>.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Portlet</td> <td valign="top">A portal-based application that supports autonomous functionality. Liferay Portal ships with over 60 useful
column17: pre-bundled portlets.</td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top">Theme</td> <td valign="top">Flexibility to change the look and feel of a given page or site with the click of a button.&nbsp; The Liferay community has contributed dozens of themes that range from clean and professional appearances to fun and wacky. See <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/downloads/themes">contributions</a>.</td> </tr> </tbody> </table></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root>
	<dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
		<dynamic-content><p>Liferay was formed by four partners from diverse technological and professional backgrounds. Our seasoned team endeavors to pioneer innovative enterprise solutions for companies worldwide.</p> <h2>Brian Chan</h2> <p>Brian Chan
column15: began development on Liferay Portal in 2000 to provide nonprofit organizations with an open source solution to facilitate collaboration on the Internet. He has since steered Liferay to become a leader in innovative open source enterprise solutions. With a strong foundation in software architecture and economics
column16: Brian has solidified open source as a low-cost
column17: high performance solution for the enterprise. His expertise in portal architecture and design has garnered him a seat on the JSR-286 portlet specification committee.</p> <p>Brian holds a dual B.S. degree in Economics and Computer Science from the University of Chicago.</p> <h2>Bryan Cheung</h2> <p>Bryan Cheung
column18: CEO and a founding partner of Liferay
column20: has an extensive background in consulting with Fortune 500 companies such as Genentech
column24: and Gateway Computers. Backed by a solid mix of technical knowledge and managment skills
column25: he has helped steer Liferay''s partner relationships and business development efforts around the world.&nbsp;</p> <p>Bryan holds a bachelor''s degree in Computer Science from the University of California
column26: Berkeley.</p> <h2>Brian Kim</h2> <p>Brian Kim is one of the original founders of Liferay
column27: Inc. and experienced technology consultant and operations manager. As COO
column28: he has led the growth of the company''s Professional Services Organization and orchestrates the ongoing operations of a fast-growing global organization. Prior to co-founding Liferay
column29: Brian worked alongside upper management at HubbardOne on internal company operations. He is also an alumnus of Accenture where he worked with marquis clients in the financial services sector.</p> <p>Brian holds a B.S. and M.S. in Computer Science from the University of Chicago.</p> <h2>Michael Young</h2> <p>Michael Young is Liferay''s CTO and brings over 10 years of enterprise computing experience to the company. Michael has held positions at Sony Electronics
column31: and the United States Navy. At Syntricity he led the overhaul of its dataConductor EP data management and reporting software platform
column32: paving the company''s way to profitability. At Liferay
column33: Michael heads up integration efforts with key technology partners such as Alfresco and ICEsoft.</p> <p>Michael holds a B.S. in Computer Science from the University of California
