column15:
MA
Boston Convention & Exhibition Center
Booth 3036

AIIM Conference & Expo is the largest and most important annual gathering of information management professionals
column16: featuring an educational program covering the breadth and depth of enterprise content and information management issues
column17:
while providing face-to-face access to nearly every major solution provider in the space.

Liferay was selected to participate in the "AIIM Enterprise Portal Vendor Smackdown":

Enterprise portals have become increasingly important prisms into enterprise content management systems.  But with at least 15 major portal packages in the marketplace
column18: how can you tell them apart? Skip the powerpoints and glossy marketing brochures to watch 3 commercial and open-source vendors duke it out with 7-minute demos to show you how their portal solution is best for your needs. If you prefer succinct
column20: this is the session for you. An expert panel of judges will keep the vendors on track
column21:
but the best part is: you vote for the winner!

The session will be held at the Boston Conference and Expo Center on Tuesday
column22:
April 17th (4:00 - 5:00 PM).

<root>
	<dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
		<dynamic-content><p>&nbsp;</p> <h2>Installation Instructions</h2><p>If you cannot use the Plugin Portlet (because your Liferay installation is behind a firewall or has no access to the Internet)
column14: you can install a plugin manually by copying it to your hot deploy directory.</p> <p>By default
column15: this directory is located in your user directory
column16: which is different for each operating system</p> <ul> <li>Windows XP: C:\Documents and Settings\&lt;user name&gt;</li> <li>Windows Vista: C:\Users\&lt;user name&gt;</li> <li>Linux: /home/&lt;user name&gt;</li><li>Mac OS X: /Users/&lt;user name&gt;</li> </ul> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>After you have started Liferay
column17: you should find the hot deploy directory in &lt;user directory&gt;/liferay/deploy.<br /> Copy the plugin there
column18: and watch the Liferay console.<br /> When you see the message &quot;registered successfully

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1611&t=1201071534338 eWeek reviewed Liferay 3.6.1.

 “It''s long been commonplace to find open-source portals that rival or better their commercial counterparts in features and capabilities. And for a few years now
column14:
open-source portals have featured intuitive and flexible browser-based administration interfaces.
All of the above is true for the open-source Liferay Portal
column15: but its browser-based administration and content creation interface goes much further
column16:
providing in-depth interactivity and capabilities that one usually finds only in desktop applications—providing this breadth of capabilities across all current-generation Web browsers.”

]]> '

column13:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p>Liferay has been enjoying great deal of success this year as a project and company. Now we''re looking to add a few more good people to our growing team. If you or someone you know fit into any of the following roles
column14: send us a resume to <a href="mailto:careers@liferay.com">careers@liferay.com</a>.</p> <h2>Job Openings</h2> <ul> <li><a href="#ajax">AJAX Developer</a></li> <li><a href="#frontend">Front End Developer</a></li> <li><a href="#consultant">Consultant</a></li> <li><a href="#seniorconsultant">Senior Consultant</a></li> </ul> <p><a name="ajax"></a></p> <h2>AJAX Developer</h2> <p>You are amazing with AJAX development and have already built great web applications that feel like desktop applications. You are comfortable with writing homegrown code or using libraries like jQuery or prototype (but you placed your bets on jQuery six months ago). You are an expert in DOM scripting.</p> <p>You are not uncomfortable working in the context of a complex Java web application even if you don''t understand its intricacies.</p> <p>You are a self starter who loves working with technology and you stay up late putting the finishing touches on your code. You don''t need to be told what to do to see what needs to get done. You are excited about working with a leading open source software company with cutting-edge opportunities at Fortune 500 companies around the world.</p> <p><a name="frontend"></a></p> <h2>Front End Developer</h2> <p>You have been working with (X)HTML and CSS for anywhere from 1-4 years. You prefer front end development because you''re creative and visual and have a good eye for design. You write standards-compliant / semantic (X)HTML and CSS without Googling the syntax or using WYSIWYG editors.</p> <p>You understand the difference between standards mode and quirks mode. You know what the box model hack is and what versions of IE it works for. You may love Firebug because it saves your life or you are so good you don''t need it. You can use Gimp
column15: Fireworks or Photoshop to cut up images and are handy with designing an icon or two in a pinch.</p> <p>You are not uncomfortable working in the context of a complex Java web application even if you don''t understand its intricacies. You won''t get scared off by scripting markup like Velocity or JQuery showing up in the code here and there.</p> <p>You are a self starter who loves working with technology and you stay up late putting the finishing touches on your code. You don''t need to be told what to do to see what needs to get done. You are excited about working with a leading open source software company with cutting-edge opportunities at Fortune 500 companies around the world.</p> <p><a name="consultant"></a></p> <h2>Consultant</h2> <p>You have 3-4 significant years (not just filling a billable seat) of experience working in deeply technical projects on client sites. You have at least a year of experience working as a technical team lead or in other client-facing situations. You have worked with business stakeholders to translate their deep understanding of their business into ones and zeroes. Clients like you because you are comfortable to work with and they trust your judgment on technology. You are familiar with different development methodologies
column16: including agile.</p> <p>Technically speaking you have very good Java fundamentals and J2EE experience. You are starting to really understand how Struts
column17: Spring and Hibernate fit together in a well-designed Java application and you have been exposed to design patterns. You are curious about the Ruby rage because you realize that a language is just a language but development is about strong fundamentals like algorithms and OOP.</p> <p>You are a fan of open source because of the amount of quality software available from the FLOSS community. You have begun to work with Liferay in your free time or on a project. You know what ant build-service means.</p> <p>You still enjoy traveling up to 90% of the time and are excited to work with a leading open source software company on great project opportunities at Fortune 500 companies around the world.</p> <p><a name="seniorconsultant"></a></p> <h2>Senior Consultant</h2> <p>You have 5-6 years of experience working in client-facing situations in deeply technical projects. As an ideal candidate you have experience with the full project lifecycle for technical implementations
column22: and deployment to production. You prefer agile development methodologies but are equally comfortable walking with clients through more traditional processes. You are more than competent in being a trusted advisor to both business stakeholders and senior architects in Fortune 500 companies.</p> <p>Technically speaking you have strong Java fundamentals and J2EE experience
column24: understand why Liferay stopped using EJBs in our latest version
column25: and have opinions about JSF
column26: Struts
column27: Hibernate and Spring. You read The Server Side or Java Lobby for fun. You know who Martin Fowler is.</p> <p>You also have a strong commitment to the philosophy of open source and are particularly passionate about Liferay. You understand why it''s significant that Liferay is still offered under an MIT license. You have been a contributor or user to the Liferay project for several years
column30: Ray or Jorge by first name
column31: and you remember when our logo used to be an alien.</p> <p>On top of all this
column32: you love to travel up to 90% of the time and you believe in the power of community to build portals and the power of portals to build community.</p> <h2>PLUSES:</h2> <ul> <li>You know the peculiarities of specific app servers
column34: or specific databases</li> <li>You have integrated Liferay with other open source products or proprietary products like Exchange or Lotus</li> </ul></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

<root>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content><p>Liferay''s professional services team is comprised of the very people who design our products. Our consultants work alongside your team to create customized solutions that address every aspect of the application lifecycle.</p> <ul> <li>Gain&nbsp;access to our&nbsp;core product&nbsp;expertise. As an added benefit
column14: your technology staff will acquire extensive product and development knowledge through working alongside our developers.</li> <li>Gain security in knowing that you will be up and running faster and safer.</li> <li>Optimize your usage of Liferay Portal to maximize your existing and future IT investments.</li> </ul> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>Our consulting services include
column15: but are not limited to:</p> <table width="100%"> <tbody> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Installation assistance</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Assist with installing
column17: and configuring Liferay Portal.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Migration assistance</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Assist with migrating from any portal to Liferay Portal.</li> <li>Assist with migrating applications onto Liferay Portal.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Custom solutions</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Provide customized solutions to meet the diverse needs of enterprises.</li> <li>Create a proof of concept pilot before investing heavily in your portal project.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">System analysis and design</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Analyze end user needs and business requirements within a portal infrastructure.</li> <li>Assist with software design of your portal project.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Front end theme design</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Create front end themes that reflect your company''s image.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Code validation</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Provides a validation service for your portal development projects.</li> <li>Offers you peace of mind that your projects are on track.</li> <li>Reduces cost and time spent troubleshooting errors.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Architecture assistance</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Ensure best practices approach to portal development.</li> <li>Provide a detailed plan of recommended enhancements.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="consult-point">Performance tuning and scalability</td> <td class="consult-detail"> <ul> <li>Provide recommendation of hardware/software environment tailored to your organization.</li> <li>Optimize Liferay Portal performance.</li> <li>Assist with setting up a clustered environment for scalability and fault tolerance.</li> </ul> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h2>Contact Liferay Professional Services</h2> <p>For more information regarding Liferay consulting services

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1535&t=1201073136743 "We have been very happy with Liferay portal since 2004 and hope to see it extend to other areas of our organization."

-- Jim Myers
column15:
NCSA

]]> Organization Profile

The National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA)
column16: one of the five original centers in the National Science Foundation''s Supercomputer Centers Program
column17: opened its doors in January 1986. Since then
column18: NCSA has contributed significantly to the birth and growth of the worldwide cyberinfrastructure for science and engineering
column19: operating some of the world''s most powerful supercomputers and developing the software infrastructure needed to efficiently use these systems (for example
column23:
the first readily available graphical Web browser). Today the center is recognized as an international leader in deploying robust high-performance computing resources and in working with research communities to develop new computing and software technologies. 

Cyberenvironments is one of NCSA''s five key focus research areas and aims to give research communities the means to fully exploit the extraordinary resources available on the Internet (computing systems
column25:
and tools). 

Challenge

The center is involved in a wide range of projects to use portal technology in research and education settings
column26: integrating heterogeneous resources (data
column30:
and providing an integrated collaborative environment for distributed users to work online in a secure environment. 

A wide range of portal frameworks have been used in these efforts but for its next-generation collaboration software for Cyberenvironments research
column31: the "CyberCollaboratory"
column32: the center looked again to find a mature
column34:
well-supported open platform for development. 

Key criteria included:

  • JSR-168 compliance
  • Collaboration and web 2.0 features and functionality such as wikis
column36: and other communication tools such as chat
column38:
and document sharing
  • An open development platform that allowed for the customization and development of new tools
  • A mature product and a strong community

    • Resolution

    "After evaluating a number of portal options
column39: Liferay came out on top in terms of stability
column40: developer-friendliness and performance
column42:
Associate Director for Cyberenvironments. “It also offered superior management capabilities and a large number of working out-of-box portlets that were JSR-168 and WSRP compliant."

Since selecting and implementing Liferay Portal in 2004
column43:
NCSA''s Cybercollaboratory has been evolving as part of NCSA’s efforts to build national cyber infrastructure to support innovative collaborative research in environmental science and engineering.

Today
column44:
the portal is at the core of community collaboration and group coordination with over 400 registered users from all over the world. It is one of a set of coordinating technologies that together provide unique capabilities for integrating local and remote work and for capturing and exploiting data and interaction provenance.

Beyond providing collaboration capabilities with the Cybercollaboratory
column45: NCSA has also developed a wide range of prototype capabilities that demonstrate the types of rich services that will be available to researchers working in planned national environmental observatories. These include data analysis tools
column46: Google Map Mashups with a real-time sensor monitoring
column47: social network analysis tools
column48:
among many others including customized portlets for:

  • Workflow and modeling services
  • Data management
  • Collaboration
  • Semantic document repositories
  • Social recommender system

In addition to Liferay''s technical qualifications
column49: it was important to NCSA to have a solution with a strong community around it. "This guarantees that our team has and will have a built-in support system around our efforts
column50: " said Myers
column51:
"We have the freedom to add innovative science-centric features on a general framework that is supported by a very broad range of organizations."

Looking forward
column52: NCSA hopes to expand its usage of Liferay to other areas
column53: including collaborative computer network security investigation
column55:
and grid-based visualization.

column14:
Germinus

]]> Company Profile

EducaMadrid represents the Madrid
column18: 600 schools. EducaMadrid is sponsored by the Consejer¨ªa de Educaci¨®n de la Comunidad Autonoma de Madrid
column19:
an organism of the Spanish public administration.

Challenge

EducaMadrid needed an application which would not only tie together students within a class but also establish relationships between other classes
column23:
EducaMadrid required an application that would scale to meet their large user base and best fit their budget. Cost was also a concern as commercial applications often come with a high price tag along with a per user cost. EducaMadrid needed the following from an application:

  • Ability to scale to the total number of users and students
  • Flexible and customizable layouts dependent on the user
  • Community resources accessible to everyone

 

Resolution

Germinus
column25: selected Liferay Portal as the framework application for EducaMadrid. Liferay''s framework provided the ability to create an extranet comprised of a set of websites with educational news and content
column26:
as well as an intranet with websites that were personalizeable based on the hierarchal role of the registered user.

By leveraging Liferay''s capabilities
column27:
Germinus was able to:

  • Implement a Web builder (creation of websites based on portlets)
  • Establish virtual communities (group chat
column29:
etc.)
  • Implement LDAP authentication and user management
  • Allow content management
  • Integrate with MvnForum
  • Integrate with legacy applications made with struts
  • Develop specific tools: contextual help system
column31:
etc.

 

With Liferay''s robust UI
column32: Germinus was able to customized the look and feel of the portal according to the user''s hierarchal role and/or grade. Teachers have a "desktop" displaying classroom materials while students access a different UI catering to their learning needs. As the students progressed to higher grades
column33:
the actual interface becomes increasingly more complex.

EducaMadrid saved hundreds of thousands of dollars by implementing Liferay Portal. With each portlet acting as a standalone web application
column34:
Liferay provides the means to extend functionality without huge refactoring costs.

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1546&t=1201073373159 "Liferay Portal was by far the most cost effective and efficient portal technology
we considered.”

--Steve Bergman
column15:
Goodwill Industries International

]]> Company Profile

Goodwill Industries International is one of the world''s largest nonprofit providers of education
column17: and career services for people with disadvantages
column20: lack of education or work experience
column24: local Goodwills collectively provided employment and training services to more than 720
column25:
000 individuals.

Challenge

Goodwill needed a solution that would provide the technology framework behind its public web site www.goodwill.org and its new intranet site. Known as MyGoodwill
column26: this new site was to create a landmark organizational tool for the international nonprofit company
column27: enabling thousands of Goodwill staff worldwide to collaborate
column29: and engage in real-time learning. Additionally
column31: as with other nonprofits
column32:
staying within budget is always a major concern. A solution that provided the most powerful and flexible technologies at the lowest cost was a high priority.

Resolution

When Goodwill first selected Liferay
column33: their IT team had many reservations about going with an open source product. As progress continued
column35: "First and foremost is an accelerated return on investment
column36: which allows us to make additional site features possible sooner. Liferay Portal is easily adaptable to Goodwill''s data center architecture and the diverse combination of technologies that we employ. Finally
column37:
it offers exceptional robustness and scalability. Liferay Portal was by far the most cost effective and efficient portal technology we considered."

Liferay implemented the following:

  • Collaborative chat and message board capabilities
  • Distribution of knowledge via Blogs
  • "Wiki" pages that were regularly updated by visitors
  • Interface to Computer-Based Training modules
  • Document repository

 

Liferay easily exceeded all of Goodwill''s expectations. Customizations that Bergman expected to be done in six to eight weeks were done over one weekend. Not only did it provide all the desired functionality
column39:
long-term cost savings. All fears were relieved  when the Liferay implementations were completed.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1600&t=1201073373169 /image/journal/article?img_id=1602&t=1201073373171 /image/journal/article?img_id=1604&t=1201073373174 /image/journal/article?img_id=1606&t=1201073373177 /image/journal/article?img_id=1608&t=1201073373180 /image/journal/article?img_id=1610&t=1201073373184 /image/journal/article?img_id=1559&t=1201073373217 /image/journal/article?img_id=1560&t=1201073373222 /image/journal/article?img_id=1561&t=1201073373227 /image/journal/article?img_id=1562&t=1201073373232 /image/journal/article?img_id=1563&t=1201073373236 /image/journal/article?img_id=1564&t=1201073373241 '

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1803&t=1201073560795 "Liferay Portal has been a key enabler of our marketing efforts in Pantech’s new North American market. Having kept pace with 12 product releases in 2006 alone
column14:
the technology is clearly nimble and powerful but also simple enough to maintain with minimal support. We foresee Liferay as an integral part of Pantech’s IT investment in the future"

 

– Philip Hyun
column20: Inc. and Pantech C&I Co. - is the number two mobile phone company in South Korea and is the seventh largest handset manufacturer in the world. Pantech has been responsible for a number of breakthrough innovations in the mobile technology sector
column21: including the introduction in 2004 of the world''s first fingerprint recognition camera phone
column22: as well as award winning camcorder
column25: a Cypress
column26: California–based subsidiary of Pantech & Curitel and Pantech Co.
column29: markets and develops wireless handsets and telecommunications products throughout North America as part of the Pantech Group. For additional information
column30:
visit the PWI website at www.pantechUSA.com.

Challenge

Pantech made its entrance into the US cellular market in the fall of 2005
column31: planning to offer its products through all major US wireless carriers. A crucial part of the agreement with the carriers was the existence of a website to which customers could be directed for product support and information. Hence
column32:
a public site was mission critical for both their US carrier clients and target end users.

As Pantech was already an established international company
column33: it needed the site to quickly adapt to the existing look and feel of its corporate brand. Spanish language support was also essential for the multilingual US market. Lastly
column34: due to the need to cater to deadlines and timelines set by the market and its partners
column35:
Pantech was looking for a fast solution that could be easily managed over time.

Resolution

In response to these immediate marketing and business needs
column36: Liferay Portal was chosen by Pantech’s digital advertising company
column38: as the best solution for its pressing deadline. In particular
column39: the easy to manage front-end would allow graphic designers to quickly match Pantech’s existing global branding. Meanwhile
column40: Liferay’s flexible and feature-rich backend would be easy to customize for the IT team in a short period of time. It also allowed for simple
column42:
long-term multi-lingual support.

Beyond meeting these basic requirements
column43:
Pantech and URi continue to be impressed by the scope of business value that Liferay delivers:

  • Manageability and low costs of ownership – The built in content management system (CMS) and its ability to scale in capacity is a perfect fit to handle the large loads of marketing content that Pantech needs maintained over time. Moreover
column44: the CMS’ intuitive and user-friendly interface is wholly maintainable without the involvement of large IT teams with significant technical skill
column45:
allowing Pantech to enjoy low costs of maintenance and ownership.
  • Business agility – Given the nature of Pantech’s business
column46: timely updates are required to synch up to a product release calendar rather than a timeline established by the preferences of an IT team. In fact
column47: Liferay’s agility helped Pantech USA support the launch of 12 products in 2006 alone. With rapid changes to their website happening with each product launch
column48:
the CMS system enabled content to be pushed up on their site quickly and accurately.
  • Extendibility into new markets – Liferay is compatible with a large global product company such as Pantech as it provides a quickly implementable solution to cater to international market expansion. Liferay provides the client with ease of mind and a confidence that the marketing efforts in its new U.S. market are reliably met with each product launch. The company recently built its Canadian website on Liferay as well
column49:
leveraging the technology’s multi-lingual support for French-Canadian audiences.

 

Looking forward
column50:
Pantech and URi hope to leverage Liferay Portal for a number of other marketing and business endeavors.

column13: ' /image/journal/article?img_id=1554&t=1201073653521 “Liferay’s turnaround on our project was exceptional. Thanks to their ideas and input
column14:
the end result is an excellent working relationship and a quality site that exceeded HanseMerkur’s expectations.”

 

- Dr. Horst Karaschewski
column16:
HanseMerkur

]]> Company Profile

HanseMerkur is a Hamburg-based insurance group with more than 130 years of experience in private health insurance
column17: its main business segment. The company
column18: which is also Germany''s third-largest travel insurer
column19: offers a full range of life
column22: accident and motor insurance. With gross premiums written of 671 million EUR in 2005
column23:
HanseMerkur''s investment portfolio registered at around 3 billion EUR in 2005.

Challenge

HanseMerkur set a goal to dramatically improve its Web presence and to increase the amount of information available online to prospective customers. The company envisioned a site populated with marketing content in mixed formats like HTML
column24: graphics and PDF. Visitors to the site would interact with online content including contracts
column25: job applications and downloadable forms. Hence
column26:
a content management system (CMS) capable of managing its 350+ pages of content was high on the list of desired capabilities and features.

Resolution

After evaluating a number of solutions
column27: HanseMerkur decided an open source portal would work best as a service-oriented architecture (SOA) framework. HanseMerkur then quickly chose Liferay Portal as the best candidate to provide a foundation for this enterprise-wide SOA. Liferay’s ease of use
column28:
scalable CMS and high degree of functionality compared to that of the other portal offerings further solidified the company''s decision.

Moreover
column29: HanseMerkur was impressed with the Liferay consulting team’s vision and depth of knowledge. HanseMerkur traveled to the CeBIT conference specifically to meet with Liferay representatives
column30: after which a proof of concept was delivered. As Liferay provided further ideas and vision for the portal’s potential
column31:
this initial effort grew into a full collaborative development and integration engagement leveraging personnel from HanseMerkur and Liferay’s German and U.S. organizations.

Despite a detailed yet oft-changing list of specifications
column32: the HanseMerkur site was successfully delivered under tight deadlines. The end result was a portal that exceeded the client’s original vision and showcases the fruits of its collaboration with Liferay. Besides the strong
column34:
the portal also delivers added site functionality and enhanced marketing potential through a Search Engine Optimization (SEO) feature that HanseMerkur sponsored and which was immediately added to Liferay''s 4.2 release.

Liferay Portal will continue to provide a framework for further enterprise integration throughout the HanseMerkur organization. Following the first successful team effort and the establishment of a strong working relationship
column35:
Liferay is currently working with HanseMerkur on new development and enhancements. Innovations leveraging Liferay Portal to streamline HanseMerkur’s back-end processes and thereby bolster the company’s competitive edge in the insurance marketplace are among the key projects in progress.

  • Scalability – Liferay Portal’s CMS easily manages HanseMerkur’s 350+ pages of mixed content. Liferay Portal enables HanseMerkur to add hardware incrementally to comfortably scale the site in complexity and size.
  • Enhanced marketing potential – Search Engine Optimization (SEO) now enables the site to automatically and dynamically optimize its visibility on leading Web search engines
column36:
keeping the HanseMerkur brand at the forefront of consumer minds.
  • Improved site functionality – The portal acts as an aggregator of services and allows the end-user to complete an insurance policy via the website.

    •

--Chris Matthews
column15:
Smart Furniture & Smart Fixtures

]]> Company Profile

SmartFixtures.com is second half of SmartFurniture.com
column16:
a leading online furniture reseller delivering innovative modular space organization solutions.

The company was originally imagined in 1995 at Stanford University to address real space-management headaches in residential and home office environments. SmartFurniture.com was born
column17: delivering a "Design on Demand" concept with innovative modular furniture
column19: and shelving systems. The company has been featured on major television networks such as HGTV and ABC and boasts awards in customer service and innovation from the likes of Dell and the National Retail Federation. Smart Furniture is a privately held Delaware corporation headquartered in Chattanooga
column21:
USA.

SmartFixures.com targets corporate buyers across a wider variety of industries and is driven
column23:
by Salesforce.com.

Challenge

SmartFixtures.com required the use of technology that would appropriately reflect the company''s  dedicated to innovation and functionality. While the sister site
column25: addressed the home retail market
column26:
SmartFixtures.com demanded the ability to manage accounts for a number of different industries and markets.

The organization was running solely on Linux and Java
column27: with the site driven by Salesforce.com and featuring new cutting edge technology. To meet its technical needs
column28: the Smart Fixtures team needed a next-generation
column29: best of breed platform with flexibility and the ability to provide heavy web-services support on the backend. To meet its business needs
column30: the site also had to be extremely easy for administrators
column31:
a number of sales account managers and other non-technical users to manage and learn.

The site was tested in Jetspeed
column32: Infoglue and a number of other JSR-168 compliant technologies but ultimately
column33: the team wanted a Java-based platform. Given the content-heavy business model
column34:
SmartFixtures.com also wanted an enterprise-ready content management system.

With this in mind
column37:
that Liferay was the best choice. "I was tracking Liferay Portal for the past 2 or 3 years and knew it was the perfect ffit in terms of usability and technical innovation."

Resolution

Since implementing Liferay
column38:
SmartFixtures.com has delivered a number of impressive extensions to Liferay''s core functionality.

In particular
column39:
it highlights the Shopping Portlet:

The team extended and enhanced the original Liferay Shopping Cart Portlet to allow individuals to add items to their cart while not logged-in to Liferay. Additionally
column40: enhancements were made to expedite the create account/login and checkout process
column41: making the whole process a 3-4 click experience. To further extend the user''s experience
column42:
the team also added an Adobe Flex based product catalog browser that enables fast searching and comparison of products that is seamlessly integrated with the Liferay checkout basket.

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1512&t=1201069615784 CIGNEX provides complete open source solutions for Web content management
column18: and content intelligence.  It uses a limited and highly select set of best-of-breed enterprise products for its projects deployed in a wide range of industries; among its more notable clients are Cisco

and the University of California.

This course is designed to help you come up to speed on the functionality and development of Liferay Portal. It will help you to increase your productivity as well as introduce you to valuable new features.

NEW 4.3 Release

Come and learn about the new features Liferay Portal 4.3 has to offer!

Hands-On Training

We will take you through the entire process of portlet development and teach you industry best practices.

Subject Matter Experts

The course will be led by the Liferay experts who designed the software.

Development Environment

For development we will setup Tomcat on Eclipse and use MySQL for the database. Although Liferay can be used with any application server and database
column22:
the above setup is the fastest in terms of development. We may also touch upon installation with other application servers and databases as well.

Prerequisites

Basic knowledge of Java and Servlets is required. The course will be intensive
column23:
but we will make sure to answer any questions you have to ensure that you have a solid grasp of the technology by the end of the course.

  • Minimum System Requirements: 1.4 GHz 512MB RAM

  • Wireless Card Required

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><div align="justify">March 18 - 23
column15: Utah<br />Salt Palace Convention Center<br /><a href="https://www.novellbrainshare.com/slc2007/exhibitor/custom/BS07_ERC_Exhbt_Hall_Scale.pdf">Booth 230</a><br /><br />With the sunsetting of the exteNd Portal platform (support ending 6/9/09)
column16: many Novell customers needing a portal solution are looking for compelling alternatives with long-term viability. Liferay Portal is a mature open source portal platform
column17: and its growing community of Novell users and compatibility with Novell products make it a viable replacement and alternative to exteNd. <br /><br />At Brainshare 2007
column18: Liferay''s chief software architect Brian Chan and CTO Mike Young (<a href="http://www.novellbrainshare.com/slc2007/exhibitor/custom/BS07_ERC_Exhbt_Hall_Scale.pdf">Booth 230</a>) will demonstrate how to deploy a full open source stack&nbsp; using Novell SUSE Linux 10
column20: and Liferay Portal 4.2 (or most current version). They will also demonstrate how to use Liferay''s LDAP administration GUI to integrate with Novell eDirectory
column21: as well as how to extend the default Liferay user profile with additional attributes found in an LDAP directory.<br /><br />Key features of the portal and a high level objective comparison with other offerings will be highlighted so that attendees who provide Novell professional services can make informed recommendations to clients. Case studies of companies using Liferay on SUSE and/or with eDirectory will also be presented.</div><div align="center">---------------------</div><div align="justify">Liferay will also be collaborating with a new technology partner
column23: to preview new features and functionality enhancements:<br /><blockquote><ul><li><strong><em>Liferay running behind Access Manager 3.0</em></strong> &ndash; TriVir has created code that will allow Liferay to consume an HTTP Basic Authentication Header. The Access Manager sends a basic auth header to Liferay when the user logs in
column24: providing an elegant and maintainable single sign on solution. As Novell''s Access Manager 3.0 also comes with a J2EE security agent for a number of popular application servers
column25: many Novell users will find integrating this type of security directly into applications to be straightforward and flexible.</li></ul><ul><li><strong><em>PasswordSmith Portlet</em></strong> &ndash; TriVir has also developed the first eDirectory Universal Password-enabled JSR-168 Portlet. With Liferay''s new Plug-In Manager
column26: this portlet can easily be deployed live into an existing running portal environment. But the real power of this portlet is that it is written to leverage password policies and Universal Password from eDirectory.</li></ul><ul><li><em><strong>LDAP Dredging Feature</strong> of Liferay Portal 4.2.1</em></li></ul><ul><li><strong><em>Novell IDM integration</em> </strong>with Liferay via the Liferay web service interface</li></ul><ul><li><strong><em>Subscription portlet </em></strong>&ndash; This custom portlet from TriVir allows users to subscribe to newsletters based upon the business unit
column28: ready to go. A demonstration will show:</li></ul><blockquote>a. How to deploy a portlet or war file<br /><br />b. How to configure portlet preferences<br /><br />c. How to place a portlet instance on a page<br /><br />d. The custom code of a working &quot;JSF style&quot; portlet<br /></blockquote><blockquote>&nbsp;</blockquote></blockquote>Liferay welcomes you to join them at&nbsp; Booth 230 in the Salt Palace Convention Center to see some of the interesting new technologies being developed through this new partnership. <br /><br /><br /><div align="center"><img alt="" src="http://www.trivir.com/trivirlogo.gif" /> &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <img width="152" height="36" alt="" src="http://www.liferay.com/html/themes/brochure/images/custom/liferay-logo.png" /></div></div></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p><a target="_blank" href="http://www.sda-india.com/conferences/jax-india/">JAX India 2007</a><br />May 28-31
column15: IISc<br />Bangalore India <br /><br />Liferay is a <a target="_blank" href="http://www.sda-india.com/conferences/jax-india/sponsor_overview.php">Gold Sponsor</a> for this year''s JAX India
column16: one of the largest and most important events for enterprise technologies in Europe and Asia.<br /><br />Join us in Bangalore as CEO
column17: Bryan Cheung and Chief Software Architect
column18: Brian Chan speak at three separate <a target="_blank" href="http://www.sda-india.com/conferences/jax-india/speakers.php">sessions </a>on portal technology and the market: <br /><br /><strong>Session: </strong>Leveraging SOA and ESB for an Enterprise Architecture<br /><strong>Speaker: </strong>Bryan Cheung
column19: CEO<br /><br />The Gartner Group predicts that by 2008
column20: 80% of development projects will be related to service oriented architectures. BEA
column22: and others are pouring millions into marketing around their software''s readiness to take on the crucial task of providing a SOA. But are there open alternatives? This session will showcase the Liferay architecture
column23: including the exposure of services via EJBs
column25: JSON
column26: and SOAPWeb Services to facilitate the rapid deployment of composite applications in an SOA context. Also highlighted will be integration with the Apache ServiceMix enterprise service bus (chosen for its compatible license)
column27: and Liferay''s leveraging of the JBPM Workflow engine.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Session: </strong>JSR 286: The New Portlet API<br /><strong>Speaker: </strong>Brian Chan
column29: the first version of the Portlet API
column30: defined standards for the expected behavior of portlets and portlet containers. However
column31: the fledgling specification lacked clear definitions in key areas of portlet and portlet container behavior. As a result
column32: developing real world applications in JSR 168 almost always requires going beyond the specification to fulfill business requirements. JSR 286 improves on the JSR 168 spec by providing for inter-portlet communication
column35: and more. This session will discuss some of the topics related to the JSR286 (except confidential aspects) and cover real world examples where the new definitions might make development easier than with JSR168.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Session: </strong>Why Java Kicks the Crap Out of PHP and Ruby<br /><strong>Speaker: </strong>Brian Chan
column38: and other developer communities are notorious battlegrounds for the perpetual wars over which programming framework reigns supreme. Yet at the end of the day
column39: technology is just a tool to be used to get the job done
column40: and different problems are best addressed with different tools. The success or failure of a project more often depends not on the tools used
column41: but whose hands they''re in. This session will discuss the various strengths and weaknesses of these three popular platforms. We will also see how Liferay
column42: an open source Java portal
column43: can be an aggregator of portlets using different technologies

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="company-image" type="image">
    <dynamic-content></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="company-link" type="text">
    <dynamic-content><![CDATA[]]></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="company-link-name" type="text">
    <dynamic-content><![CDATA[]]></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="quote" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p><em><font size="3">&quot;With CAPassist
column14: Liferay Portal and Ancud IT Services have been leveraged to deliver a workflow portal that structures and accelerates the internal processes of CAP GmbH. Based on open source components
column15: the portal empowers CAP GmbH&rsquo;s various divisions and their external service providers to collaborate effectively&quot; </font></em></p><p align="right">- Christoph Kalka
column17:
CAP GmbH</p></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p><strong>Company Profile</strong><br /> <br /> CAP GmbH is the operating company of <a href="https://www.happydigits.de/servlet/hdhtml/index" target="_blank">HappyDigits</a> founded by Deutsche Telekom
column20: Europe''s largest department store and mail order group. With over 26 million customer cards
column21: HappyDigits is one of the most popular customer incentive programs in Germany. <br /> <br /> CAP GmbH develops and markets the bonus system
column23: and manages the reward system. The company specializes in the areas of customer loyalty and incentive programs supporting large and medium size companies with customer relationship management. Its competencies range from technology and back-office
column25: bonus management and web presence to market analysis
column26: reporting and others.<br /> <strong><br /> Challenge</strong><br /> <br /> CAP GmbH coordinates complex marketing campaigns that reach several million addressees and works with external suppliers such as marketing agencies and copy shops. The result is a complex production process with a multitude of single steps
column29: CAP GmbH was looking for:</p> <ul> <li>An application accessible to the involved internal departments as well as to the external suppliers.</li> <li>An additional budgeting tool to record the costs for balancing and evaluation. Campaign processes take place in an extremely time dependent environment. Clear process mapping was of major importance.</li> <li>A user-friendly interface to ensure users would be more productive using the application.</li> </ul> <p><strong><br /> Resolution</strong><br /> <br /> CAP GmbH was at first open to both open source and proprietary solutions for its portal framework. After evaluating both options
column31: CAP GmbH and system integrator
column32: Ancud IT
column33: chose Liferay Portal for its wide range of functionalities
column34: technical flexibility and high ROI. <br /> <br /> Because Liferay Portal is JSR-168 compliant
column35: Ancud IT was able to quickly integrate different applications within the new portal. Liferay&rsquo;s standards-compliance also significantly facilitates the replacement of applications within the portal infrastructure. Outdated or obsolete software can be easily removed and replaced. <br /> <br /> By leveraging Liferay&rsquo;s capabilities
column36: Ancud IT was able to deliver a workflow tool
column39: CAPbudget:<em><br /> <br /> Workflow</em><br /> CAPassist gives users personalized task management and context-sensitive navigation. Automatically scheduled e-mails help users to continuously monitor production progress. In addition to versioning
column40: Liferay Portal&rsquo;s automatic time scheduling and document management features are invaluable to the CAPassist portal. <br /> <br /> Liferay Portal allowed Ancud IT to structure and automate working steps and accelerate them
column41: thus making processes independent of place and time. It also greatly reduced fault probability.<br /> <em><br /> Budgeting</em><br /> To address budgeting
column42: Ancud IT integrated a budgeting and reporting tool
column43: CAPbudget. The ability to compare estimated and real costs at a glance greatly facilitates standardized and precise budget planning. The tool also features important accounting functions like reversals and transfers.<br /> <br /> Through CAPbudget
column44: third parties such as internal departments or parent companies can be directly charged for services provided by CAP GmbH. Calendar management makes sure that no budgets &ldquo;get lost&rdquo; after monthly or project balances. Reporting functionalities with an Excel interface makes direct analysis and evaluation of budgets in Excel possible.<br /> <br /> Due to the success of CAPassist and its high degree of acceptance
column45: CAP GmbH is now planning to introduce Liferay Portal to the entire company. Several additional integrations will be built
column46: including:</p> <ul> <li>Call center operations</li> <li>Microsoft Outlook integration for improved calendar management</li> <li>Integration of a unit cost tool based on Hyperion S-Base</li> </ul> <p><br /> In keeping with the open source character of the project
column47:
CAP GmbH is planning to publish parts of the source code developed on the Internet to make it available to the community to serve administrators and developers as a best-practice example.</p></dynamic-content>
  </dynamic-element>

-- Russ Danner
column15:
Christian Science Monitor

]]> Client

The Christian Science Monitor is an international daily newspaper published Monday through Friday. Founded in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy
column16: it''s now also a multimedia website
column19:
and a downloadable PDF of the print version.

Challenge

An increasing emphasis on the web was pushing the Christian Science Monitor to invest significant efforts in to converging its print and web content. Seeking to deliver a more dynamic and interactive user experience
column20: the organization set out to revamp its website
column22:
and better control work flow. 

Improving the readability of story content and optimizing use of website space for advertising were also priorities. Hence
column23: the organization sought a flexible web publishing solution that would extend control over the layout and plugability of website articles
column24: images and other site components. A solution would also ideally provide a virtualized web page structure that would allow the editorial and publishing staff to anticipate needed changes
column25: quickly refactor presentation of information
column26:
and better leverage reusable content assets.

Lastly
column27: the underlying desire for more flexibility and options inherently demanded a solution that would grow with the site and accommodate future business objectives. A proper solution
column29:
would be able to handle increasing loads of content and highly fluctuating traffic scenarios characteristic of a press site. 

Because the project would include many new components
column30: the Christian Science Monitor knew it would have to rely on a strong
column31:
collaborative team of both open source and proprietary vendors with integration expertise to ensure success.

Resolution

After reviewing several portal offerings
column32: the Christian Science Monitor chose Liferay Portal for its ease of use
column34: and superior out of the box functionality. In particular
column35: Liferay’s comprehensive collection of prebundled portlets differentiated it against other products on the market
column36:
both commercial and open source. 

Beyond these technical merits
column37: the Christian Science Monitor also acknowledged the degree to which a network-based open source business model would foster transparency for open communication with their vendors. It was also attracted to Liferay’s company’s vision
column38: which was well-aligned with its own non-profit /charitable mission. Involving a core team of developers and extensive interaction with the newsroom and publishing staff
column39:
the resulting web publishing portal quickly achieved the organization’s goals. 

  • Content and publishing – Liferay Portal provided a platform on which content created on Alfresco’s content management system was easily aggregated. In collaboration with the Alfresco team
column40:
a custom portlet was created to pull content to tie neatly into Alfresco’s workflow.
  • Layout and user interface – The first portal to offer drag and drop lay out functionality at that time
column41:
Liferay Portal gave Christian Science Monitor editors immense control over the redesign and layout of site content and articles.
  • Personalization option – Beyond supporting the desired customer logins and personalization
column42: Liferay Portal provided expanded functionality with the set of collaboration tools provided
column43:
providing a more dynamic and interactive user experience.
  • Scalability – The scalability of Liferay Portal’s underlying architecture was put to the test shortly after deployment: The capture
column44: holding and release of Jill Carol
column45: a Monitor correspondent held hostage in Iraq prompted an exclusive 10 part series released each day for which the site easily served nearly 200
column46:
000 page views per hour during the site’s most active 8 hours of each day.

Looking forward
column47: the Christian Science Monitor intends to remain active in Liferay’s community. Said Russ Danner
column48:
the Christian Science Monitor’s lead Architect on the portal implementation project: “We strongly believe in leveraging the expertise of our open source partners and community. Liferay has been evolving and innovating in the open source portal market for quite some time and the strength and maturity of its community is reflected in the maturity of the product’s features.”

]]> Company Profile

The Consortium for the Commercial Promotion of Catalonia (COPCA)
column19: in affiliation with the Ministry of Innovation
column21:
is the Catalan government’s tool to promote the internationalization of Catalan companies and their adaptation to the new guidelines of the global economy.

COPCA comprises the Government of Catalonia
column22: the Catalan Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the main sector and export associations
column23: along with entities related to the world of trade
column24:
finance and overseas trade training. In total there are almost a hundred members.

As a service centre for the internalization of Catalan companies

column26: market assessment and international consolidation of companies. They are located in Catalonia as well as in COPCA’s international network of Business Promotion Centers
column27:
spread over 31 countries.

Challenge

COPCA wanted to build a virtual space where Catalan enterprises could share experiences
column28: knowledge and support from both government and other organizations. Because COPCA’s offices are spread worldwide
column29: it was necessary to build a collaborative platform that would be accessible by employees in any location
column31:
resources and applications.

The original technologies used to do this at COPCA varied by region so an upgrade also served as an opportunity for organizational homogenization.

Resolution

 

After assessing a number of technology solutions
column32: both open source and commercial
column36: the decision was made to use Liferay Portal. The new virtual space
column38: (www.anella.cat) is the new virtual space that powers Catalonia’s internalization. Today
column39:
Liferay is at the core of COPCA’s virtual desktop.

L''Anella''s aim is to service professionals of all areas: business organizations
column40: associations
column42: it is a tool for communications
column43: knowledge sharing
column44: and business process management for customers and employees

providing:

  • Integrated user management system. Centralized user
column47: communities

and privileges management using an LDAP
  • Community management and collaborative tools
  • Application
column50:
and service aggregation
  • Business Process Management

  • Document Management System

column53:
installation and personalization.

The resulting platform is currently being used by COPCA’s employees and more than 10.000 registered users from various Catalan companies. New services and applications are added to the system each month to resolve new requirements as needed by the community.

¨DMawae Morton

First Nations Futures Program

]]> Company Profile

Kamehameha Schools is a nonprofit institution dedicated to educating children of Hawaiian ancestry. Towards this goal
column16:
Kamehameha Schools is working in partnership with other indigenous communities that hold land trusts from Alaska and New Zealand to create a fellowship program for leadership development in natural resource management.

The fellowship program
column18: partners with a consortium of academic institutions. In collaboration with indigenous community leaders and environmental experts
column20:
teach and facilitate an annual Leadership Institute for fellows.

Challenge

Kamehameha Schools was challenged to bring together several geographically dispersed communities. A key objective was to provide collaborative tools that would enable and encourage communication among the participants in Alaska
column21:
Hawaii and New Zealand.

The portal needed to fulfill a marketing role and publicize the fellowship program to participating communities
column23:
donors and the general public.

Resolution

Wired Moon
column24: the consulting company working in collaboration with Kamehameha Schools
column25:
was tasked with selecting an appropriate tool to serve the unique needs of the fellowship program.

After reviewing several portal products Liferay Portal was selected for its superior out-of-the-box functionality
column26: ease of use and low cost of ownership. Liferay Portal compliance with JSR standards also allowed easy integration with other portal tools (outside of Liferay)
column27: as well as simple customization on top of the portal. This granted the organization great flexibility in building a sustainable solution that could be customized in the long-term for its specific and changing needs. Meanwhile
column28:
the ability to easily customize the look and feel of the external website addressed marketing and branding issues with a minimal investment of time.

However
column29: the real benefit of Liferay Portal for the fellowship program was its ability to facilitate a sense of community. The organization depended heavily on the Document Library
column30: Image Gallery and built-in content management system to provide a common space for sharing. Out of the box portlets
column31: such as the Calendar and Message Boards
column32:
facilitated communication within the community.

Wired Moon enhanced the portal with a streaming video portlet for displaying key videos within internal and external portions of the site. Wired Moon also integrated 123FlashChat into the portal to provide a more interactive and integrated chat experience for users.

Giste benefited from the advantage of using mature open source software to build a scalable solution on solid technological architecture while cutting expenses.”

 

--Victor Fari?a Infante
column16:
Queres Tecnologias

]]> Company Profile

Giste Cervecera S.A. is a well known hotel and catering group headquartered in Galicia
column17: Spain. Its presence is mainly in Galicia but is expanding to the rest of Spain with a projected growth of 150% for 2007. In light of this planned expansion
column18:
Giste raised the necessity of improving its information management.

System integrator
column19:
Queres Technologies was selected to assess the possible solutions and build a system to meet these needs.

Challenge

A key problem of small and medium sized companies is the management of information—inadequate storage leads to difficulties in getting to documents and information contributed by various members of the company. The poor access leads to duplication of information becomes common
column20:
which then further exacerbates the already poor storage resources.

In preparation for its ambitious growth objectives
column21:
Giste wanted to improve communication and access to information in order to achieve more streamlined and homogenous business processes across its various locations. Giste was also looking for a single point of access to all corporate resources so that it could progressively provide its employees with human resource services. Some of the identified necessities included:

  • A tool that permits notification
column22:
resolution and tracking of all the incidences created in the different premises.
  • An application for the visualization of payslips that allows the workers to check them in a quick way.
  • A tool that would track and monitor corporate expenses.
  • A documentation management system that would allow users to share and organize documents.

    •  

    Solution

    Queres Technologies determined that the most fitting solution for Giste’s needs would be developed based on JSR-168 standards. Because all applications created (checking of payslips
column23: introduction to extra hours and management of incidences) under these standards would be able to be dropped into and used in any other JSR-168 compliant portal
column24:
this development strategy provided the client the greatest degree of flexibility in the long-run.

After thorough evaluation of various commercial and open source enterprise portal solutions
column25: Queres selected Liferay Portal for its development philosophy and dedication to compliance
column26:
the maturity of the product and its forward-looking product roadmap.

Liferay Portal provided a solid base for future implementations of customized tools—Its compliance to standards guaranteed the continuity of development done in future evolutions of Liferay. The portal gave Giste a means to standardize and reinforce its corporate values and aims throughout its organization
column27:
which ultimately supported employee training.

Instead of wasting thousands of euros on licenses of commercial applications
column28:
Giste has seen the advantage of using mature open source software to cut expenses and build a scalable solution that has a solid technological architecture.

Business Analyst - Jason''s Deli

]]> Company Profile

Jason''s Deli originated in 1976 in Beaumont
column17: with 12 menu items. Today over 100 items
column18: from traditional Reubens to New Orleans Muffalettas
column19:
are served daily at 135+ locations across 17 states. Jason''s Deli corporate and franchise locations employ over 1000 managers and corporate staff.

Challenge

Jason''s Deli needed a solution that would serve as a company intranet and be open and flexible enough to add and tailor features specific to the varied tasks of the restaurants and support department. The development team wanted an open-source application with growth potential that was JSR-168 compliant. Due to the limited development resources of the relatively new IT department
column20:
it was important to find an application that would require minimal customization and development while fitting into an already stretched budget.

Resolution

Jason''s Development team
column25: chose Liferay Portal Enterprise to fit the bill. Liferay''s aesthetic quality initially caught their eye
column26:
and after closer inspection they realized that it matched all of the major criteria.

Liferay has enabled Jason''s Deli to:

  • Eliminate an expensive commercial intranet with very limited functionality.
  • Use single-authentication to access various company sites that previously required separate user identification procedures.
  • Reduce the amount of "clutter" in an individual''s e-mail box by rerouting group discussions to the message boards.

Jason''s Deli''s future plans for their Liferay application include:

  • Integrating back-of-the-house software applications.
  • Help Desk issue recording and tracking.

Just as other companies have realized through using Liferay products
column27:
Jason''s Deli saved thousands of dollars annually while increasing functionality and enabling unlimited future growth through the implementation of Liferay Portal.

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1802&t=1201072462152 Company Profile

Castilla y Le¨®n is one of the largest regions in Spain.

Challenge

Junta de Castilla-Le¨®n wanted a "Digital Magazine" to broadcast general interest information for its educational portal
column14:
Educacyl. But there was one caveat: the "Digital Magazine" needed to be oriented towards non-technical users that would divide the content creation process into two parts. The first part would allow users to create the content being shown in the portal. The second part needed to be a tool to that enabled users to easily layout the various content components previously created.

Resolution

With all its prebundled portlets
column15: Liferay Portal was decidely the best candidate. These portlets allowed the user of the "Digital Magazine" to have visual tools for editing their content. Through the CMS
column16: the portal already had tools that separated editing and managing content. Additionally
column17:
it was easy to visually apply various layout templates to different parts of the "Digital Magazine."

Thanks to these portlets
column18:
the "Digital Magazine" is now an active section of the Educacyl portal. It has a professional look-and-feel yet is easy to use by non-technical people.

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1620&t=1201072493521 "The portal system is an excellent tool. It provides stable connectivity of our internal systems with Internet
column14:
allowing us to supply passengers with up-to-date and reliable information on line. We also appreciate practically limitless number of portlets and easy to use administration interface."

– Ing. J¨¢n Palko – Operations and Business Manager

]]> Company Profile

Ko?ice Airport was built in 1951 near the city of Ko?ice
column16: and has been growing ever since. In December 2004 Ko?ice Airport became a civil international airport. By the end of the same year
column17: the airport succeeded in opening a new T2 terminal. In the summer of 2005
column18:
it received a “Construction of the Year? award at the 11th National public contest. Ko?ice Airport has also recently exceeded the record for the number of handled passengers. In January 2006 the TwoOne consortium has been recommended to the Slovak cabinet as the winner of a tender for 66-percent stakes in Bratislava and Ko?ice airports. Investments in Ko?ice airport should exceed €24 million by the end of 2015.

Challenge

Ko?ice Airport management was primarily seeking a new attractive web site. But after seeing the power a web portal delivers in connectivity between the Internet and the company Intranet
column19: the management instantly changed their minds. Although the project was limited by a modest budget
column20: the Airport managed to gain a sufficient grant from the Ministry of transportation
column22: and telecommunications. The basic requirements included a user friendly environment
column24: display of up-to-date information (e.g. arrivals and departures
column25: weather
column26: statistics
column28: and a modern design. Ko?ice Airport hoped to get an attractive Internet presentation and effective intranet system
column29:
both connected in an interactive application.

Resolution

The delivery of a custom portal system exceeded the expectations of Ko?ice Airport. Many services were provided building on top of the Liferay Portal:

  • Layout of tree structures
  • Full screen resolution layout
  • Improved Journal portlet:
    • Full support of UTF8 for templates and structures
    • Managing article discussions
    • Counters for most read or discussed articles
    • Assigning articles various categories for layouts
    • Image thumbnails for articles
    • Journal article with embedded Flash animations
    • Access to remote services using a proxy
    • Real-time display of arrivals/departures from external systems
    • English version

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1592&t=1201073156563 “After reviewing a number of other options
column14:
we believe Liferay remains the leading portal solution out there. Its dedication to open standards is a key factor in using the Liferay portal for community driven air quality work.”

– Stefan Falke
column16:
Environmental and Chemical Engineering at Washington University in St. Louis

]]> Company Profile

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Washington University in St. Louis are working toward realizing the vision of the Networked Environmental Information System for Global Emissions Inventories initiative (NEISGEI – pronounced ‘niceguy’) with the goal of applying the latest information science and technologies to open web access of disparate emissions data and analysis tools.

Challenge

In order to foster research
column17: analysis and decision-making NEISGEI needed a framework for networking global air emissions inventories in a way that fostered aggregation and integration of the separate content inventories provided by the many participating groups of the air quality community. Accordingly
column18:
the EPA sought a solution that included a web portal and tasked the CAPITA team at Washington University in St. Louis with developing an appropriate platform.

As CAPITA had a long history of working with portals as a means of promoting open discussion
column19: the concept of virtual community was very familiar to them. They
column21: keenly monitored the standards for portal interoperability
column22: so the ability to share content with other portals was a key factor in the selection process. Other portal requirements included a catalog of distributed emission inventory data
column23: tools for processing and analyzing the data
column24: means for registering new data and tools
column25:
and an environment for collaboration among international research groups and policy-makers.

After reviewing a number of commercial and open source products
column26: the CAPITA team chose to develop its community air emissions portal using Liferay because of its commitment to interoperability and open standards. Liferay was also chosen for its ease of customization
column27:
which aligned with the NEISGEI vision for a truly collaborative and community-based sharing environment.

Solution

Leveraging Liferay Portal''s functionality and its dedication to open standards
column28: the CAPITA team created the NEISGEI web portal through which emissions data and visualization/analysis tools can now be accessed. While the initial users came primarily from the scientific community and those involved with air quality management and policy development
column29:
the community is open to the public at large as an educational resource for anyone interested.

With the new portal solution
column30: the EPA and the Air Quality community is able to facilitate better communication
column31: sharing and learning
column32: which ultimately results in more effective policy development. In the portal environment users can contribute their own content and provide feedback on the scientific objectives of the collective using Liferay''s out of the box collaboration tools such as message boards
column34: blogs and a centralized document library
column35: among others. Web tools and applications enabling data access
column36:
visualization and analysis have also been provided.

With support from Liferay
column37: further portlet interoperability features were introduced and will continue to develop. Leveraging Liferay’s compliance with JSR-170 industry standards
column38: the NEISGEI portal will be able to exchange information between portlets within the portal itself as well as between the many disparate portal applications used by the air quality community. This
column39: along with data integration
column40: continues to be an area of greater vision and development. Said Stefan Falke
column42: Environmental and Chemical Engineering at Washington University and CAPITA’s NEISGEI project lead: "With its dedication to open standards and interoperability
column43:
Liferay will serve us for years to come."

Disclaimer: Liferay is not endorsed or sponsored  by Washington University in St. Louis or the US Environmental Protection Agency and the opinions expressed in this case study are not necessarily those of the University or the Agency.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1688&t=1201073156576 /image/journal/article?img_id=1593&t=1201073156578 /image/journal/article?img_id=1690&t=1201073156581 /image/journal/article?img_id=1594&t=1201073156583 /image/journal/article?img_id=1692&t=1201073156586 /image/journal/article?img_id=1595&t=1201073156589 /image/journal/article?img_id=1694&t=1201073156592 /image/journal/article?img_id=1596&t=1201073156595 /image/journal/article?img_id=1696&t=1201073156598 /image/journal/article?img_id=1597&t=1201073156601 '

column13: ' /image/journal/article?img_id=1675&t=1201073923739 "Our view is that a portal is fundamentally an application integration tool rather than a solution in and of itself
column14: so we were intent on applying our program costs to rapid customization
column15: not license fees. This turned out to be the right mindset because within a month of initial rollout
column16:
our Liferay-based customer portal helped us edge out competitors in several hard-won contracts. Sales people actually started calling HQ to thank the development team."

 

- Eric Nathanson
column17:
Oakwood

]]> Company Profile

Oakwood Worldwide is the largest temporary housing provider worldwide. With 40 years of multi-family housing experience and 30 years of industry leadership in corporate housing
column18: Oakwood Worldwide is the most experienced leader in temporary furnished apartments. With access to over 400
column21: as well as select locations in Canada
column24:
85% of Fortune 500 firms depend on Oakwood Worldwide.

Challenge

To maintain a competitive edge over other housing providers
column25: Oakwood''s management recognized the need to upgrade their disparate legacy systems. By implementing a more efficient and cost-effective process model
column26: Oakwood hoped to increase profitability and improve the customer''s ability to book and schedule reservations. With over 400
column28: Oakwood needed an application that would not only query all availabilities that matched a customer''s criteria
column29:
but would also allow sales agents to effectively meet those requests.

Oakwood needed the following from an application:

  • A Profiles System that would allow sales agents to easily update the properties they are responsible for.
  • Content Management System that would manage the layout and content of the website.
  • A website with a new look and feel that would improve the customer''s ability to search and book apartments.

Resolution

Oakwood Worldwide selected Liferay and its enterprise portal to implement the functionality it needed. By leveraging Liferay Portal Enterprise''s framework
column30:
Liferay implemented the following:

  • Profiles Portlet - Liferay helped build a Profiles portlet that allowed sales agents to manage properties they were responsible for. This included the ability to upload property images
column31: descriptions
column32:
and other information that would help a sales agent in closing a sale.
  • XSLT CMS - Oakwood''s website is driven by Liferay''s Content Management System. Via an XSLT templating system
column33:
Oakwood can control the content displayed on the site along with its layout.
  • eInvoicing - Liferay used web services to integrate a .NET invoicing system into its own portlet within Liferay Portal.

    • As opposed to spending hundreds of thousands of dollars for a commercial application''s license alone
column34: Oakwood Worldwide saw the advantage of using Liferay''s open source software to cut costs and build a well architected
column35:
long-term solution.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1918&t=1201073923751 /image/journal/article?img_id=1676&t=1201073923754 /image/journal/article?img_id=1920&t=1201073923757 /image/journal/article?img_id=1677&t=1201073923760 /image/journal/article?img_id=1922&t=1201073923763 /image/journal/article?img_id=1678&t=1201073923767 /image/journal/article?img_id=1924&t=1201073923770 /image/journal/article?img_id=1679&t=1201073923774 '

column13:

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1658&t=1201073585526 "As small business owners
column14: my brother and I saw the power in tools like shared calendars
column17: and document management. Unfortunately small businesses have to spend large amounts of money to implement these tools
column20:
BEA and Oracle. We know first-hand how expensive and time consuming these products are. Small businesses can''t possibly make that kind of commitment. We developed Officegateway to give small business owners a chance to compete."

 

- Chris Nadeau
column21:
President - Officegateway

]]> Company Profile

Evolving Solutions
column24: provides cost-effective software development services and solutions to an array of small to mid-size businesses.  Through innovation
column25: teamwork
column26: superior products
column28:
Evolving Solutions is passionately committed to making a significant impact in people''s lives!

Challenge

Evolving Solutions wanted to offer a solution to its customers that enabled small and medium-sized businesses to use technology to achieve business growth
column30:
and success.

Before the launching of OfficeGateway (www.officegateway.ca)
column31:
such sophisticated tools were only available to large enterprises with large IT budgets and a dedicated IT team. OfficeGateway was presented with the challenge to make these enterprise-style technologies affordable and available to companies ranging from 1 person start ups to an organization of 100 people or more.

Resolution

OfficeGateway developed a hosted solution that is user-friendly and affordable.  The integrated suite of portlets gives new and growing businesses essential tools to collaborate
column32: communicate
column33:
and manage information anytime and from any Internet connection.

Evolving Solutions selected Liferay Enterprise Portal as the framework application for OfficeGateway. Liferay''s framework provided the ability to create a Hosted "On Demand" Portal solution
column34: which is comprised of a set of pre-built portlets developed by Liferay
column35:
along with customized portlets developed by Evolving Solutions and integrated with Liferay.

By leveraging Liferay''s capabilities and pre-built portlets
column36:
Evolving Solutions was able to get OfficeGateway to market faster. Pre-built portlets include:

  • Shared Calendar
  • News (RSS Feeds)
  • Bookmarks
  • Polls
  • Maps
  • Stocks
  • Currency Converter
  • Translator
  • Weather
  • Dictionary

 

Portlets developed and integrated into Officegateway by Evolving Solutions:

  • Administration Portlet for the Hosted Solution
  • Support Portlet
  • WebMail
  • Contact Center
  • CRM/Invoicing Portlet - Lightweight CRM tool including opportunities
column39: dashboard reports
column40:
invoice tracking and reports
  • Company Directory
  • Company Announcements
  • Document Library (Shared and Individual)

    •  

    Evolving Solutions saved hundreds of hours in time
column41:
which in return saved thousands of dollars by implementing a hosted portal solution via the Liferay framework.
