' /image/journal/article?img_id=1598&t=1201072566033 "Liferay gives you the ability to build standalone web applications and to combine them to build a portal. This results to easiness of extending functionality."

- Kostas Karkaletsis
column14:
Gnomon Informatics S.A.d

]]> Company Profile

The Managing Authority of the Regional Operational Program of Central Macedonia 2000 - 2006 in Thessaloniki
column16: is the authority that manages the activation
column19:
and transparency of Operational Programme of Central Macedonia. The total budget of the Operational Programme for 2000-2006 is 1.5 billion euro. The projects funded by the Operational Programme are selected by the Managing Authority following the criteria described in the Program Complement and approved by the Monitoring Committee.

Challenge

The Managing Authority needed an enterprise portal system with content management capabilities that would allow the staff of the organization to update the site content on a daily basis and manage the large number of citizens and organizations accessing the portal for updated information:

  • The exploitation possibilities offered by the location of the Region
  • News regarding the implementation progress of Regional Operating Program activities
  • Update on the calls for proposal launched or terminated
  • Press releases

 

Resolution

Gnomon Informatics S.A.
column20: an IT consulting company located in Thessaloniki
column22: selected Liferay Enterprise Portal as the framework for building the portal. Significant effort has been given towards applying multilingual behavior in all new portlets in order to create multilingual portals in both the user interface and the data. By leveraging Liferay''s capabilities
column23:
Gnomon was able to:

  • Build a lot of new portlets: Web Content Manager (creation of dynamic html pages with table of contents)
column25: Frequently Asked Questions
column26: Banner Management
column29:
and Newsletters
  • Implement multilingual mechanism to data layer and supporting translations to any number of languages of the data. The portal now can be multilingual in both the user interface and data presentation.
  • Develop specific tools: JavaScript menus
column30:
search engines

 

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1723&t=1201072566046 /image/journal/article?img_id=1599&t=1201072566048 /image/journal/article?img_id=1725&t=1201072566051 /image/journal/article?img_id=1600&t=1201072566054 /image/journal/article?img_id=1727&t=1201072566057 /image/journal/article?img_id=1601&t=1201072566060 /image/journal/article?img_id=1729&t=1201072566063 /image/journal/article?img_id=1602&t=1201072566066 /image/journal/article?img_id=1731&t=1201072566070 /image/journal/article?img_id=1603&t=1201072566074 /image/journal/article?img_id=1733&t=1201072566077 /image/journal/article?img_id=1604&t=1201072566081 /image/journal/article?img_id=1735&t=1201072566085 /image/journal/article?img_id=1605&t=1201072566090 /image/journal/article?img_id=1606&t=1201072566094 /image/journal/article?img_id=1607&t=1201072566098 '

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1646&t=1201072598802 Company Profile

Telecentros is a network of public offices that belongs to a government program called Internet Rural that promotes the use of new technologies in rural areas. Telecentros is part of Red.es -- a public company run by the Ministry of Industry
column16: Red.es opened public offices throughout many rural towns that provided free Internet access. In one of these Telecentros offices
column17:
residents in the area could surf the web and begin to utilize the new technologies.

Red.es needed a web portal that displayed all Telecentros office locations in Spain and provided a description of the services they offered. Having over 3
column20: the portal needed to connect all of the Telecentros offices. Achieving this was important in providing communication and collaboration tools for its users. Another requirement was that all the tools needed to be easy to use as many of residents had littleto no experience with a computer
column21:
let alone the World Wide Web.

Resolution

Germinus developed the Telecentros portal using Liferay Portal. They found that Liferay Portal had a user-friendly design. It was powerful in connecting users yet simple enough for those who had little or no experience with the Internet. Liferay Portal exceeded the requirements of the client.

' /image/journal/article?img_id=1581&t=1201073665514 Company Profile

HealthMarkets is America''s leading provider of affordable health insurance for the individual
column15: and small business markets. They are also leaders in student and hourly employee insurance nationwide. Their promise of affordable coverage is delivered through their dedicated agent and broker force of over 4
column16:
000 professionals who are trained and licensed through the company''s agency associates in 44 states.

Challenge

After struggling to develop and maintain BEA''s portal
column17: Health Markets needed to find a cost-effective enterprise portal as a replacement for its employees and agents. Rather than building an ad-hoc web application from the ground up
column18: Health Markets wanted to develop on top of a stable portal platform that would provide all the necessary permissioning
column20: and frameworks out-of-the-box. With two projects running in parallel
column21:
Health Markets needed a means of componentizing development teams and codebases while still deploying to one standard web application.

Resolution

Given the fact that they needed to meet an aggressive deadline
column22: Health Markets employed the training and consulting services of Liferay to accelerate development cycles. Together
column23:
Health Markets and Liferay were able to build:

  • Agent Management System - The Agent Management System couples together isolated systems within the company and aggregates them into a dashboard of reports. These reports allow for managers to track the utilization of agents within their division as well as analyze the spread of products sold.
  • Leads System - The Leads System Portal application was designed to increase the efficiency of the sales force by automating the distribution and management of sales leads from the company databases to the agents on the field. This process entailed the handling of millions of data records involving complex business rules and custom user preferences. The system allowed the end user to clearly and efficiently view and execute on potential sales orders. Liferay Enterprise Portal integrated with the various existing Health Markets systems and aggregated these resources onto a single platform.
  • Newsletter - By leveraging Liferay''s CMS
column24:
editors were able to create and publish newsletters on a monthly basis.

 

]]> '

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p style="line-height: 1.8em;">In an environment where technology infrastructures are complex
column14: Liferay''s International Partner Program provides you with extensive training and support around our award winning portal.</p> <p style="line-height: 1.8em;">While other industry programs segment functions that you can participate in and charges for participation in additional revenue streams
column15: the Liferay International Partner Program enables you to immediately participate in many key revenue streams.&nbsp;</p> <p style="line-height: 1.8em;">Backed with Liferay''s support
column16: you have an enormous amount of flexibility to capture these opportunities. Choose from the following partnership categories and levels to best leverage your company''s strengths.</p> <div> <ul> <li style="padding-bottom:5px"><strong>Services Partners</strong> engage in sales
column18: and development services for Liferay products in their respective territories.</li> <li style="padding-bottom:5px"><strong>Premier Partners</strong> are carefully selected by Liferay to stand as the premier providers of sales
column23: and Level 1 support for Liferay products in their respective territories.&nbsp; Only one Premier Partner for each territory will be appointed by Liferay.&nbsp; Premier Partners have a regional presence and have made significant commitment to Liferay products and training.</li> <li style="padding-bottom:5px"><strong>Preferred Partners</strong> engage in sales
column25: and development services for Liferay products in their respective territories.&nbsp; With the full support of Liferay and Liferay''s appointed Premier Partner
column26: the Preferred Partner Program is ideal for vendors that have extensive technical expertise but could benefit from the marketing
column28: and support services offered by Liferay and Liferay Premier Partners.</li> </ul> </div> <p style="line-height: 1.8em;">Successful Liferay Partners share Liferay''s vision and effectively execute business objectives.&nbsp; Liferay''s International Partners:</p> <div style="line-height: 1.8em;"> <ul> <li>Have extensive technological expertise</li> <li>Share Liferay''s commitment to providing innovative solutions for clients</li> <li>Holds recognizable and trusted presence in their territories</li> <li>Are motivated to continually refining Liferay product skills</li> </ul> </div></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><style> .sample-table td { background: #1C2633; border: 2px solid #141B24; } .sample-table .header { background: #304256; } </style> <h1>Liferay Samples</h1> <p>The sample portlets and layouts were developed by Liferay to teach the community how to create portlets and layouts. Contact us at staff@liferay.com if you would like us to promote components you have developed.</p> <p>The sample portlets are JSR-168 compliant and can be hot-deployed. Portlet WARs are componentized applications and cleanly separated from the portal. Our goal is to provide the community with enough sample portlets so that everyone can go out and create JSR-168 compliant portlets to meet real-world needs.</p> <p>Layout templates are used when adding content so that users can easily arrange portlets inside a custom design template. See the documentation for more information on Layout Design Templates.</p> <table class="sample-table"> <tr> <td class="header"> <h2>Sample JSR-168 Portlets</h2> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <p><a href="LINK">Sample ICEfaces JSF Sun Portlet</a> (New For Use with Liferay 4.3.0rc1)<br /> This portlet shows how to use ICEfaces and the Sun implementation of JSF as a portlet. It demonstrates Ajax-powered field validation
column15: and file upload.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample DAO Portlet</a><br /> This portlet has one data access object that allows users to add
column17: and delete entries. This portlet does not utilize a MVC or persistence framework in order showcase the minimum steps of writing a portlet that communicates with a database.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample JSP Portlet</a><br /> This portlet shows how to include JSPs from a portlet.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample JSF Sun Portlet</a><br /> This portlet shows how to use the Sun implementation of JSF as a portlet.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample JSF MyFaces Portlet</a><br /> This portlet shows how to use the MyFaces implementation of JSF as a portlet.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample JSON Portlet</a><br /> This portlet shows how to use JSON and AJAX to pull an application through a portlet.</p> <p><a href="LINK">Sample Struts Portlet</a><br /> This portlet uses Struts as a MVC framework to cleanly separate business logic from display logic. Developers who are familiar with Struts can use this portlet as an example of how to migrate existing Struts applications from a servlet environment to a portlet environment.</p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td class="header"> <h2>Sample Layout Templates</h2> </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <p><a href="LINK">Sample Pack 01 Layout Templates</a><br /> This sample pack includes the 2-1-2 layout template. The first row is made up of two columns of portlets. The second row is made up of one column. The third row is made up of another two columns.</p> </td> </tr> </table></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

column14: Liferay and their Premier Partners constantly monitor the respective regions to create an optimum business environment for all our partners to grow.</p> <p class="faq-question">Q: What is the difference between Premier
column16: and Services Partners?</p> <p>A: All partners work together with Liferay to deliver value and innovation to our clients.</p> <p>The <strong>Services Partner</strong> level is the basic partner level for professional services providers who want to signal to the marketplace that they have committed resources and experience using the Liferay Portal platform.</p> <p><strong>Preferred Partners</strong> take that commitment a level further by working with Liferay to approach the market together in sales
column18: and business development activities.</p> <p><strong>Premier Partners</strong> have the highest commitment to and strongest relationship with Liferay and advise Liferay on strategic activity in specific regions.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p class="faq-question">Q: What is required to become a Premier Partne</p> <p>A: Premier Partners must have been a Preferred Partner for at least one year and shown their investment in the Liferay platform during that time. Premier Partnership will be a natural result of a strong working relationship between a Preferred Partner and Liferay in a specific region.</p> <p><a name="liferay-annual-certification-requirement"></a></p> <h2>Liferay Annual Certification Requirement</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: Once I pass Liferay''s Skill Certification exam will I need to take another certification exam when it is time for me to enroll in the Annual Recertification Program?</p> <p>A: Once you have passed the Liferay Skill Certification exam you will not need to retake it provided your certification is current.&nbsp; Enrollment in the Annual Certification Program is required to keep your certification current.</p> <p class="faq-question">Q: How many Liferay Certified developers do I need?</p> <p>A: Certification commitments vary by Partner level. column20: and Liferay provide training for clients in their respective territory.&nbsp; Premier Partners along with Liferay provide training support for Preferred Partners. column22: Liferay is entitled to 10% of the first three calendar months of scoped work.</p> <p><a name="revenue-benefits-for-training-services"></a></p> <h2>Revenue Benefits for Training Services</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: What are the revenue benefits for training services?</p> <p>A: Only Preferred and Premier partners are entitled to provide training services. Partners will receive 70-80% of training fees for all students.</p> <p><a name="revenue-benefits-for-liferay-support-contracts"></a></p> <h2>Revenue Benefits for Liferay Support Contracts</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: What are the revenue benefits for Liferay Support Contracts?</p> <p>A: The revenue benefit for Liferay Support Contracts are determined by the level of involvement.</p> <p><strong>Support Contract Revenue Benefits Highlight</strong></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <table class="faq-chart"> <tbody> <tr valign="top"> <td width="40%" class="faq-chnp"><p>&nbsp;</p></td> <td width="20%" class="faq-chdr"><strong>Services Partner</strong></td> <td width="20%" class="faq-chdr"><strong>Preferred Partner</strong></td> <td width="20%" class="faq-chdr"><strong>Premier Partner</strong></td> </tr> <tr valign="top"> <td width="40%" class="faq-chdr">Partner sells Liferay Support Contract and provides Level 1 support</td> <td width="20%">N/A</td> <td width="20%" valign="middle" align="left">45% first year of contract

column25: 20% thereafter</td> <td width="20%">30% first year of contract
column26: 20% thereafter</td> <td width="20%">40% first year of contract
column27: 30% thereafter</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>*Please contact Liferay for revenue benefit details. All submissions must adhere to Liferay''s revenue benefit descriptions and are subject to Liferay approval.</p> <p class="faq-question">Q: Who provides support services?</p> <p>A: Preferred and Premier Partners provide Level 1 support and Liferay provides Level 2 and Level 3 support.</p> <p><a name="revenue-benifits-for-client-validation-service"></a></p> <h2>Revenues Benefit for Client Validation Service</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: Who can sell Client Validation Service?</p> <p>A: Premier and Preferred Partners are encouraged to offer Client Validation Service to enhance their services.</p> <p class="faq-question">Q: What are the revenue benefits for Client Validation Service?</p> <p>A: See chart below. Client Validation Service Benefit Highlight</p> <p><strong>Client Validation Service Benefits Highlight</strong></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <table class="faq-chart"> <tbody> <tr valign="top"> <td width="50%" class="faq-chnp"><p>&nbsp;</p></td> <td width="25%" class="faq-chdr"><strong>Preferred Partner</strong></td> <td width="25%" class="faq-chdr"><strong>Premier Partner</strong></td> </tr> <tr valign="top"> <td width="50%" class="faq-chdr"><p>Premier Partner sells Client Validation Service</p></td> <td width="25%"><p>10%</p></td> <td width="25%"><p>10%</p></td> </tr> <tr valign="top"> <td width="50%" class="faq-chdr"><p>Preferred Partner sells Client Validation Service</p></td> <td width="25%"><p>10%</p></td> <td width="25%"><p>10%</p></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>*Please contact Liferay for revenue benefit details. All submissions must adhere to Liferay''s revenue benefit descriptions and are subject to Liferay approval.</p> <p><a name="becoming-a-liferay-international-partner"></a></p> <h2>Becoming a Liferay International Partner</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: How do I become a Liferay International Partner?</p> <p>A: To learn more about becoming a Liferay Partner visit Becoming a Liferay Partner and Requirements and Benefits Description.&nbsp; Please contact Liferay at <a href="mailto:sales@liferay.com">sales@liferay.com</a> for additional inquiries.</p> <p><a name="contacting-liferay"></a></p> <h2>Contacting Liferay</h2> <p class="faq-question">Q: How do I contact Liferay?</p> <p>A: Liferay can be contacted at <a href="mailto:sales@liferay.com">sales@liferay.com</a>.</p></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><p><em>Note: All program terms are subject to change without notice.</em></p> <h2>Program Fee</h2> <p>Continuing Liferay''s reputation of being a high value
column15: our International Partner Program carries modest annual partnership fees to ensure the quality and commitment of our partner team.</p> <h2>Liferay Partner Training Program</h2> <p>The Liferay Partner Training Program is designed to eqipt our Partners with the necessary expertise to effectively implement Liferay products. Liferay''s courses are delivered from the people who designed our innovative products.</p> <p>Vendors seeking to become Premier and Preferred Partners must enroll a minimum of five developers into the Liferay Partner Training Program.</p> <h2>Liferay Skill Certification</h2> <p>Upon completion of Liferay Partner Training Program
column16: enrolled developers must successfully pass a Liferay certification examination.&nbsp; Successful completion of Liferay Skill Certification will provide your developers with the skills to implement Liferay products in mission critical projects.&nbsp; No further certification exam is necessary after successful completion of Liferay Skill Certification.&nbsp; Partners must maintain a minimum of five Liferay certified developers on staff.</p> <h2>Annual Recertification Requirements</h2> <p>At Liferay we are constantly developing new technologies so that you and your clients can stay ahead of the competition.&nbsp; Annual recertification is designed to keep your company at the forefront in Liferay product knowledge.</p> <p>Annual recertification is designed for developers who have already passed the Liferay Skill Certification exam to maintain extensive interaction with Liferay products. No further certification exam is necessary after successful completion of Liferay Skill Certification.&nbsp; Partners must maintain a minimum number of Liferay certified developers on staff depending on their partnership level.</p> <h2>Consultation and Development Services</h2> <p>Liferay Premier and Preferred Partners participate in promoting and providing consultation and development services. As Liferay Partners
column17: your company will play a critical role in developing innovative and cost-effective solutions for clients. As an added benefit
column18: Liferay Portal is issued under the MIT license
column19: which means that you are free to rebundle Liferay products and resell it.&nbsp; In addition to traditional consulting and development services
column20: you now have an additional revenue source by providing the same level of quality solutions that Liferay is known for.</p> <h2>Liferay Support Service</h2> <p>Clients demand fast and effective service when mission critical projects require additional support.&nbsp; For years
column21: Liferay Support Services has provided the support that companies can count on.&nbsp; Liferay Premier and Preferred Partners actively engage in promoting support services.&nbsp; Premier Partners
column22: selected by Liferay to oversee a specific territory
column23: provide Level 1 support. Liferay stands ready to support our partners by providing Level 2 and Level 3 support services.</p> <h2>Liferay Training Service</h2> <p>Today''s complex technology infrastructures mean that companies need their technical staff to effectively integrate different products.&nbsp; For years
column24: Liferay Training Service has been providing the training that companies need.&nbsp; Liferay Premier and Preferred Partners actively engage in promoting and providing training services to respective clients.&nbsp; Premier Partners
column25: selected by Liferay to oversee a specific territory
column26: along with Liferay are the exclusive providers of Liferay Training Service for Liferay Preferred Partners in their respective regions.</p> <h2>Client Validation Service</h2> <p>Liferay''s Client Validation Service creates value for our partners.&nbsp; Liferay Premier and Preferred Partners actively engage in promoting Client Validation Service.&nbsp; Liferay''s Client Validation Service offers assurance to our clients that the technologies will be successfully integrated.&nbsp; Liferay''s consultants fully evaluate each project submitted through the Client Validation Service and provide a complete assessment of our partners'' solutions.&nbsp; Clients will be issued a Liferay Client Validation Certificate to verify that the solutions are optimally configured.&nbsp; Clients will recognize the value that the Client Validation Service offers because they will save through reduced support issues.</p> <h2>Territory Assignment</h2> <p>Liferay International Partner Program is structured to enhance your company''s ability to penetrate your market.</p> <ul> <li>Premier Partners are carefully selected by Liferay to stand as the lead provider of sales
column30: and Level 1 support for Liferay products in their respective territories.&nbsp; Only one Premier Partner for each territory will be appointed by Liferay.&nbsp;Premier Partners have a regional presence and have made significant commitment to Liferay products and training.</li> <li>Preferred Partners engage in sales and consulting services for Liferay products in their respective territories.&nbsp; Fully supported by Liferay and Liferay''s appointed Premier Partner
column31: the Preferred Partner Program is ideal for vendors that have extensive technical expertise but could benefit from the marketing
column32: training
column33: and support services offered by Liferay and Liferay Premier Partners.</li> </ul> <h2>Joint Business Plan and Marketing Development</h2> <p>Liferay Premier Partners
column35: develops the marketing and business plan for Liferay products in their respective territories.&nbsp; Creating a proper business plan and marketing strategy means that your company will be able to maximize your resources.&nbsp; Liferay stands ready to partner with you and lend our experience so that market opportunities are fully exploited.</p> <h2>Referrals</h2> <p>To further your success
column36: lead referrals are an exclusive benefit that Liferay provides for Liferay Premier Partners.</p></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'
column39: 'BASIC-CONTENT'
column43: 'Joe Bloggs'

column13:
' Portal API

Liferay is designed to deploy portlets that adhere to the Portlet API (JSR-168). Many useful portlets are bundled with the portal (Mail
column17:
to name a few) and can be used as examples for adding your own custom portlets.

Liferay also holds a seat on the JSR-286 committee with plans to fully move  to this standard with version 5.0.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1632&t=1199718541667 '

column13:
'

Struts & Tiles

All HTTP and WAP requests go through MainServlet which extends the basic Struts ActionServlet. MainServlet processes all requests and ensures that each request is routed to the proper PortletAction. Refer to Struts for a better understanding of how the portal''s web framework functions.

Layout information for the portal is managed with customizable templates. Refer to articles about Tiles to get a better understanding of how Tiles works as a layout manager.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1633&t=1200939964417 '

'

EJB Spring Hibernate

Liferay is no longer dependent on EJBs and can be deployed on a standalone servlet container. All business logic is concentrated inside POJO implementations that are looked up and instantiated by Spring. These implementations can be modified or enhanced via Spring''s AOP and IOC capabilities.

The enterprise release of the portal wraps the POJO implementations with Session EJBs to provide heavy scaling and transaction support required by large sites. The professional release of the portal calls the POJO implementations directly to provide a light weight facade.

All data is persisted using Hibernate and is called through the POJO implementations. Liferay used to rely on CMP technology to achieve persistence
column14:
but switched over to Hibernate because of its raw speed and flexibility. Liferay is database agnostic and can run on a variety of popular  databases.

Liferay uses JAAS Web security so that when a user logs in
column15:
their principal is propogated to the Servlet and EJB tiers. Remote Session EJBs can take advantage of this by checking security and permissions at the EJB level so it does not have be duplicated else where. Local Session EJBs exposes business logic to other Session EJBs and does not specifically check for security since they cannot be called remotely. Principals are also propagated to POJO implementations that are the base classes for Remote Session EJBs.

The enterprise release uses Session EJBs which allows the deployer to separate the Web server
column17:
and database server to achieve clustering at three levels. This is true n-tier deploying because no one is forced to cluster at any single layer and allows the most flexibility for large companies.

Most of our EJBs
column19:
and Models are generated through the ant task build-service which reads the file service.xml in /portal-ejb. Each portlet that persist data has its own service.xml (do a search in /portal-ejb and you will get a list back). We copy this file to /portal-ejb when we want to generate the persistence classes for that portlet. This is an internal tool that is built on top of the XDoclet engine.

For example
column20: upon reading service.xml found in the Bookmarks portlet
column21:
the following model classes are generated. Each model class reflects a table in the database. Never edit BookmarksEntryModel. Do edit BookmarksEntry to add hand massaged code. BookmarksEntry is generated once and extends BookmarksEntryModel. This allows us the ease of generated code and flexibility of hand massaged code.


com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.model.BookmarksEntry
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.model.BookmarksEntryModel
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.model.BookmarksFolder
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.model.BookmarksFolderModel

Hibernate classes are generated that map to the model classes. This allows for an n-tier architecture for cases where your model classes are marshalled across the wire and your Hibernate classes are not.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksEntryHBM
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksFolderHBM

Persistence methods to add
column25: remove
column26:
and count the Hibernate entries are generated as the default persistence mechaninsm.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksEntryPersistence
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksFolderPersistence

Helper classes are generated that call the persistence methods. By default
column27: the helper classes call the Hibernate persistence methods to update the database. You can override this in portal.properties and set your own persistence class as long as it extends the default persistence class. This means you can customize where you store your data. It can be a traditional database
column29:
or even something else.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksEntryUtil
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksFolderUtil

Pooling classes are also created to minimize object creation. Behavior can be modified in portal.properties.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksEntryPool
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.persistence.BookmarksFolderPool

POJO implementations that extend PrincipalBean are generated to hold business logic that check the caller principal and can be called remotely. Calling getUserId() returns the user id of the current user. Calling getUser() returns the User model that represents the current user. The Session EJB that extends the POJO implementation implements PrincipalSessionBean.

For example
column30:
these classes allow you to delete a bookmark entry or folder if and only if you are the creator of that entry or folder.

These classes are only generated once if they do not already exist.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.impl.BookmarksEntryServiceImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.impl.BookmarksFolderServiceImpl

Helper classes are generated based on the POJO implementations. They help save developer time and prevent polluted code. Instead of writing many lines of code just to look up the appropriate Session EJB wrapper or POJO implementation
column31:
you simply call BookmarksEntryServiceUtil.addEntry to call the equivalent method in BookmarksEntryServiceImpl.addEntry.

BookmarksEntryServiceUtil calls BookmarksFolderServiceFactory to look up the class that implements BookmarksEntryService. BookmarksFolderServiceFactory defers to Spring and settings in portal.properties on whether to load the Session EJB wrapper or the plain POJO implementation. The Session EJB extends the POJO implementation.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryServiceUtil

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderServiceUtil

Tunneling classes are generated so that developers can call the POJO implementations over port 80. An example of this given in the section V of this document.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.http.BookmarksEntryServiceHttp
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.http.BookmarksFolderServiceHttp

Soap classes are generated so that developers can call the POJO implementations over port 80. Soap is slower than tunneling because tunneling streams requests in binary format. Soap is more flexible than tunneling because the client classes are not limited to Java.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.http.BookmarksEntryServiceSoap
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.http.BookmarksFolderServiceSoap

POJO implementations classes that do not extend PrincipalBean are generated to hold business logic that do not check the caller principal and can be called locally. These classes exist so that business logic can be easily integrated with other projects.

These classes are only generated once if they do not already exist.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.impl.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.impl.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceImpl

Helper classes are also generated.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryLocalService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryLocalServiceUtil

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderLocalService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderLocalServiceUtil

Some of our users needed to call the Local Service classes remotely
column32:
so Remote Service classes that parallel their Local counterparts are also generated.

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryRemoteServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryRemoteServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksEntryRemoteServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryRemoteService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryRemoteServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksEntryRemoteServiceUtil

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderRemoteServiceEJB
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderRemoteServiceEJBImpl
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.ejb.BookmarksFolderRemoteServiceHome

com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderRemoteService
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderRemoteServiceFactory
com.liferay.portlet.bookmarks.service.spring.BookmarksFolderRemoteServiceUtil

A lot of people stay away from Session EJBs because they are heavy and require a lot of coding. Our build scripts show that you can leverage the advantages of Session EJBs while minimizing repetitive labor so that you can strike a good balance between effort and results.

Spring gives Liferay additional flexibility. Developers can test their POJO implementations with Liferay Portal Professional in a servlet container and deploy to production with Liferay Portal Enterprise in an application server.

]]> /image/journal/article?img_id=1634&t=1200643104199 '
column39: 'Joe Bloggs'

column14:
'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><h2>SOAP
column15: RMI &amp; Tunneling</h2> <p>All of our remote POJO implementations are exposed to the external world via SOAP
column17: and our custom tunneling classes.</p> <p>We do not do this simply because Web services is a buzz word
column18: but because we find it extremely useful for integration. The following is an example of a company that leverages these resources.</p> <p><a href="http://www.3sixteen.com/">3sixteen</a> is a t-shirt company that needed to get up and running fast. In the fashion industry that relies on cutting-edge appearance and presentation
column19: 3sixteen needed to keep its Flash MX front-end &quot;brochure&quot; website&nbsp;that would not be used to sell clothing but to offer an experience through the music
column21: and articles. Due to the static nature of Flash
column22: the brochure site&nbsp;was not an e-commerce solution because products would need to be added
column24: and updated on a constant basis. To solve this problem
column25: they decided to separate their web presence into two sites: a brochure site and shopping site.</p> <p><a href="http://www.3sixteen.com/">www.3sixteen.com</a> became the&nbsp;graphic oriented&nbsp;site built in Flash and <a href="http://my.3sixteen.com/c/extranet/home">my.3sixteen.com</a> became the shopping site using the vanilla Liferay distribution. These two sites are hosted on two different Linux machines
column26: and for all intents and purposes could have resided on different continents.</p> <p>They also needed to build a mailing list to collect email addresses for all their interested customers. To accomplish this
column27: they added a JSP pop up box on their Flash site that would tell the portal server to add the email address to a contact in the Address Book portlet.</p> <p>The following is a JSP snippet that shows how the guys at 3sixteen leveraged <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/docs/api/portal-ejb/com/liferay/portlet/addressbook/service/http/ABContactServiceHttp.html">ABContactServiceHttp</a> to add a contact.</p> <p>String URL = &quot;http://my.3sixteen.com&quot;; <br /> <br /> HttpPrincipal httpPrincipal = new HttpPrincipal(URL
column31: lastName
column32: emailAddress); <br /> <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/docs/api/portal-ejb/com/liferay/portlet/addressbook/service/http/ABContactServiceHttp.html">ABContactServiceHttp</a> invoked <em>addContact</em> in <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/docs/api/portal-ejb/com/liferay/portlet/addressbook/service/spring/ABContactServiceUtil.html">ABContactServiceUtil</a>. The invocation was sent over port 80 and received by http://my.3sixteen.com/tunnel/servlet/AuthTunnelServlet. The application server made sure the authentication matched and then processed ABContactServiceUtil as if the user with the id <strong>joe_bloggs</strong> was calling <em>addContact</em>. ABContactServiceUtil then called <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/docs/api/portal-ejb/com/liferay/portlet/addressbook/service/impl/ABContactServiceImpl.html">ABContactServiceImpl</a> to do the actual work. You can trace the logic of this by viewing the source included in the generated JavaDocs.<br /> <br /> Now Joe Bloggs can log into the portal and look in his Address Book portlet to see that he has a new contact. All of the included portlets have this capability because these helper classses are generated. This means you can write applets or any other Java application to access the Session EJBs that contain your business logic. This can be a security hazard if someone had your password
column33:
so you can configure to limit the Tunnel Servlet to only listen on certain ports by editing <a href="@friendly_url_public@/guest/devzone/documentation">portal.properties</a>.<br /> <br /> You can also access the Session EJBs over SOAP and RMI. We will post more examples of that shortly.</p></dynamic-content>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><h1 class="epi-fontLg bwtextaligncenter" align="center"><strong>Liferay Teams With Pramati To Multiply Product Capability and Value</strong></h1><div align="center">&nbsp;</div><div id="story_subheadline"><div align="center">&nbsp;</div><div align="center"><em>Integrated App Server and Portal Smoothes Path to SOA<br /></em></div><p class="bwtextaligncenter">&nbsp;</p></div><!---------- END MULTIMEDIA BOX ----------><!---------- START STORY BODY ----------><p align="justify"><strong>SAN FRANCISCO--(BUSINESS WIRE)</strong>--Liferay
column14: provider of the leading enterprise-class open source portal platform
column16: a leading vendor of J2EE application servers and solutions
column17: today announced a non-exclusive partnership to help customers leverage the benefits of Liferay<span id="bwanpa2">&rsquo;</span>s SOA-enabled enterprise portal framework. Under the agreement
column18: Liferay Portal and Pramati Server will become available in a bundled version as a download on both companies<span id="bwanpa3">&rsquo;</span> Web sites and ship with a 30-day developer license.</p><div align="justify">&nbsp;</div><p align="justify">&quot;Bundling Liferay Portal with Pramati<span id="bwanpa4">&rsquo;</span>s robust application server software allows our customers to multiply the value and capability of their IT initiatives by leveraging Liferay<span id="bwanpa5">&rsquo;</span>s excellent user management
column23: Pramati Technologies.</p><div align="justify">&nbsp;</div><p align="justify">&quot;This package is timely indeed as the coming version 4.2 of Liferay Portal provides standard integration with ServiceMix ESB and the jBPM workflow engine
column25: founder and chief software architect of Liferay. <span id="bwanpa7">&ldquo;</span>These technologies allow enterprises to quickly plug in applications such as business intelligence
column26: enterprise content management
column28: and eCommerce on top of Pramati
column29: which is designed to deliver complex integrated applications with high availability and scalability.<span id="bwanpa8">&rdquo;</span></p><div align="justify">&nbsp;</div><p align="justify">Pramati expects the bundle to help its customers effortlessly build SOA capabilities into their IT infrastructure. Liferay Portal will also provide a unified user experience and a framework for extending that experience to all parts of the enterprise. The effortless nature of the bundle will allow companies to focus on developing core application functionality specific to the business.</p><div align="justify">&nbsp;</div><p align="justify">Liferay in turn through this relationship will leverage customer-driven innovation
column30: demonstrate the viability of mixed proprietary and open source environments
column31: and deliver on its promise to remain vendor-neutral with support for all major application servers.</p><div align="justify">&nbsp;</div><p align="justify"><span id="bwanpa9">&ldquo;</span>There is no reason why an enterprise should spend precious technical and financial resources on the details of integrating Pramati with Liferay

column16: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column17: open source portal and content management system announced a new partnership with CIGNEX Technologies
column18: a top ten open source consulting firm in the U.S. specializing in Enterprise Content Management (ECM) solutions. CIGNEX&rsquo;s formalized services offering around Liferay Portal for its corporate customers underscores a growing demand for Liferay in the enterprise environment. <br /><br />&ldquo;Commercial open source has entered a new stage of maturity
column20: chief executive officer of Liferay. &ldquo;Open source has been a disruptive force in the ECM and portal marketplaces
column21: with open source alternatives providing technological innovation
column23: and greater control to users at a fraction of the cost of ownership for proprietary software. CIGNEX&rsquo;s success proves the enterprise market is ready to invest in open source
column24: and we welcome the experience CIGNEX brings to this partnership.&rdquo;<br /><br />For CIGNEX
column25: Liferay is the only open source portal able to address the needs of its enterprise clients. &ldquo;Liferay&rsquo;s offering of business-class product support behind the product is a standout differentiator in the open source space

column27: chief executive officer of CIGNEX Technologies
column28: who also cited Liferay&rsquo;s technical fit to the enterprise market. &ldquo;After evaluating other products
column29: it was clear to us that Liferay Portal&rsquo;s agility and richness of feature set was the best match for our clients&rsquo; needs. We see a lot of potential in the technology&mdash;not just for ECM
column30: but also for extensions into Customer Relationship Management
column31: Enterprise Resource Planning and other major enterprise applications.&rdquo;<br /><br />The partnership is also a natural progression following Liferay Portal 4.2&rsquo;s delivery of out of the box integration with Alfresco. Along with Alfresco
column32: Liferay Portal is one of two software products that CIGNEX has committed to strategically major in.<br /><br />CIGNEX provides complete open source solutions for Web content management
column37: and content intelligence.&nbsp; It uses a limited and highly select set of best-of-breed enterprise products for its projects deployed in a wide range of industries; among its more notable clients are Cisco
column39: Epson
column40: HP
column42: UNC Healthcare
column43: and the University of California.<br /><br />With today&rsquo;s announcement
column44: CIGNEX becomes the first U.S.&ndash;based member of Liferay&rsquo;s Preferred Partner program.&nbsp; In addition to sharing business activities
column45: the two companies will work together to provide thought leadership and innovation to the open source ECM/portal software community. CIGNEX associates will be fully and regularly trained in Liferay Portal technology
column46: while CIGNEX will serve as a reseller of Liferay&rsquo;s enterprise support services. <br /><br />Liferay and CIGNEX are already collaborating on several corporate projects.&nbsp; For more about Liferay Portal
column47: visit www.liferay.com.&nbsp; Additional information about CIGNEX can be found at www.cignex.com.<br /><br /><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong><br />Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column48: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. Liferay clients include Discovery Education
column50: and the Christian Science Monitor. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles. For more information
column51: please visit www.liferay.com. <br /><br /><strong>About CIGNEX Technologies: </strong><br />CIGNEX is the leading provider of open source Enterprise Content Management solutions for businesses and government agencies.&nbsp; Using industry-standard platforms
column52: CIGNEX develops applications that are less expensive
column53: more extensible
column54: and easier to support than the alternatives offered by proprietary vendors.&nbsp; By combining a range of consulting
column58: CIGNEX offers multiple solutions that can be rapidly optimized for each customer&rsquo;s requirements.&nbsp; CIGNEX customers include Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories
column61: University of North Carolina School of Medicine and OKI Semiconductor.&nbsp; CIGNEX was founded in 2000 and is headquartered in Santa Clara
column62: CA.&nbsp; For additional information about CIGNEX please visit http://www.CIGNEX.com or call 408.327.9900.<br /><br /></em></p><div align="center"><em>----<br /></em><div align="left"><br /><strong>Contact:</strong><br />S&amp;S Public Relations

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><div align="center">&nbsp;<strong>Liferay Partners with TriVir
column14: Novell Experts <br />Offer Portal Alternative for the Enterprise</strong><br /><em>Co-exhibiting at Novell Brainshare 2007</em></div><p><strong><br /></strong></p><div align="justify"><strong>LOS ANGELES--(BUSINESS WIRE)--</strong>Liferay
column15: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column16: open source portal and content management system announced a new partnership with TriVir
column17: a company of seasoned Novell alumni majoring in portal services and identity management. The relationship was formed to offer Liferay Portal as a compelling alternative for enterprise users.<br /><br />With Novell dropping support for its exteNd Director portal product in 2009
column18: many Novell enterprise customers in need of a portal solution are looking for new options with long-term viability. TriVir approached Liferay
column20: to build dedicated solutions for this audience in a Novell environment as an exteNd replacement. Said Britt Courtney
column22: &ldquo;Looking at our customers and the market potential for Novell integrated solutions our best long term strategy has always contained Liferay as a component of a competitive
column23: flexible and long lasting technology stack. Liferay Portal&rsquo;s maturity on the market
column24: its growing community of Novell users and compatibility with Novell products made it our platform of choice for creating a viable replacement for Novell exteNd.&rdquo;<br /><br />&ldquo;This partnership with TriVir couldn&rsquo;t have come at a better time
column25: &rdquo; said Liferay CEO
column26: Bryan Cheung. &ldquo;TriVir&rsquo;s expertise in identity management and Novell technology will be a great asset in meeting the demand we see from the enterprise market. It has already yielded enhanced integration with Novell and could result in even a full- blown Liferay Portal Novell Edition.&rdquo;<br /><br />The companies will debut several of the developments at this year&rsquo;s Novell Brainshare conference in Salt Lake City Utah. There
column27: Liferay''s chief software architect Brian Chan and CTO Mike Young (Booth 230) will demonstrate how to deploy a full open source stack using Novell SUSE Linux 10
column29: and Liferay Portal. Key features of the portal and a high level objective comparison with other offerings will be highlighted so that attendees who provide Novell professional services can make informed recommendations to clients.<br /><br />Additionally
column30: TriVir (Booth 530) will showcase new features of a &quot;Novell Enabled&quot; Liferay portal
column31: including:<br /><br /><ul><li><em><strong>Liferay running behind Access Manager </strong></em>&ndash; TriVir has created code that will deliver a nice
column32: neat single sign on feature. The security for Novell''s Access Manager 3.0 works with a number of popular application servers
column33: making this a good fit for many Novell users.</li><li><em><strong>PasswordSmith portlet </strong></em>&ndash; The first eDirectory Universal Password-enabled JSR-168 Portlet developed by TriVir. Simply drop it into an existing portal environment. The real power of this feature is that it is written to leverage password policies and Universal Password from eDirectory.</li><li><em><strong>Subscription portlet </strong></em>&ndash; TriVir&rsquo;s custom portlet that allows users to subscribe to newsletters based upon the business unit
column34: or LDAP organizational unit.</li><li><em><strong>Novell Identity Management integration</strong></em> with Liferay via the Liferay web service interface.</li></ul><br />Innovations to come include a Novell IDM 3.5 enabled Liferay portal and other custom portal tools. &ldquo;The investment around Liferay is in line with the requests and needs of our market
column35: &rdquo; said Courtney. &ldquo;We look forward to showcasing some of the interesting new technologies being developed through this new partnership at Brainshare.&rdquo;<br /><br /><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong></em><br /><br /><div align="justify"><em>Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column36: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. Liferay clients include Discovery Education
column38: and the Christian Science Monitor. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles. For more information
column39: please visit www.liferay.com.</em></div></div><div align="justify"><br /><em><strong>About TriVir:</strong></em><br /><em>TriVir
column40: LLC was founded in 2003 by a small group of former Novell consultants and engineers. These tried and tested professionals have many years of experience in delivering proven
column41: real-world solutions. This experience has given them a deep understanding of networks and network-associated technologies.</em><br /><em>This background in real-world experience allows TriVir to deliver practical solutions that can transform a complex maze of cables and machinery into an easy-to-use
column42: secure computing network.</em><br /><em>TriVir''s goal is to reduce maintenance requirements and cut administrative costs for all clients through effective design and thoughtful planning. </em></div><p><em><br /></em></p><div align="center"><em>----<br /><br /></em><div align="left"><strong>Contact:</strong><br />S&amp;S Public Relations

column18: was demoed as the default platform for the new Novell Teaming + Conferencing collaboration product during a morning keynote at the 2007 Novell BrainShare conference.<br /><br />Novell Teaming + Conferencing is based on SiteScape&rsquo;s new ICEcorps open source collaboration product and allows employees to use virtual workspaces to share and access documents
column21: and to convene real-time Web conferences. Built for the enterprise
column22: Liferay Portal&rsquo;s impressive out-of-the-box collaboration tools and the maturity of its technology made it a fitting platform for Novell Teaming + Conferencing and ICEcorps. <br /><br />&ldquo;Liferay was an obvious choice for ICEcorps because of its maturity and scalability
column24: SiteScape&rsquo;s Chief Technical Officer. &ldquo;We are excited about the opportunity to involve the Liferay community in our project.&rdquo;<br /><br />Also
column25: unlike other proprietary portal solutions
column26: Liferay Portal can run on any application server
column27: database server and operating system. &ldquo;Liferay Portal does not limit SiteScape&rsquo;s ICEcorps audience to any particular technology stack&rdquo;
column31: &ldquo;Using Liferay ensures that existing technology investments do not have to be jettisoned and that future changes will not require an overhaul of your portal solution. Liferay Portal was created with long-term interoperability in mind and we are thrilled that Novell Teaming + Conferencing and Sitescape users will enjoy the enduring benefits of using our technology. We look forward to seeing more of SiteScape&rsquo;s involvement in our community.&rdquo;<br /><br /><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong></em><br /><em>Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><div align="center"><strong><font size="2">Liferay Partners With Novell</font><br /></strong><em>Provides Enterprise-Class Solutions to SMBs as <br />Part of Novell Market Start<br /></em></div><p><strong><br />LOS ANGELES
column15: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column16: open source portal and content management system today announced its participation in Novell Market Start.&nbsp; The Market Start program offers small and medium businesses (SMBs) enterprise-class solutions with easier deployments and at a fraction of the cost.<br />&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;&ldquo;Liferay&rsquo;s membership in Novell Market Start makes a lot of sense given the existing overlap in our user bases
column18: Bryan Cheung. &ldquo;Liferay Portal is equipped with the tools and technology to address the needs of a large enterprise but our open source licensing brings us significant popularity among smaller organizations as well.&rdquo;<br /><br />Offered under the business friendly MIT license
column19: Liferay&rsquo;s portal framework and over 60 prebundled tools
column20: including a built-in content management system and full suite of collaboration tools
column21: can be downloaded at no cost and reworked or re-packaged with no legal repercussions. Moreover
column22: Liferay Portal allows organizations with limited resources to avoid overhauls of existing IT investments as it is the only open source portal that is compatible with all major application servers
column23: databases and operating systems. <br /><br />&ldquo;Liferay offers our customers and partners&nbsp; a wide collection of enterprise-class portal tools and the option to customize them as their business grows.&rdquo;&nbsp; said Justin Steinman
column24: director of marketing for Linux and Open Platform Solutions atNovell. While Liferay is certified Ready for for SUSE Linux Enterprise
column25: Liferay also offers out-of-the-box integration with key Novell products such as Novell eDirectory and Novell Identity Manager along with Novell-specific security-related tools.&rdquo;<br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />Added Cheung
column26: &ldquo;The beauty of open source is that the quality of your IT and business processes is no longer determined by your size. It makes the playing field more competitive and gives management room to focus on growth. This is one of the main reasons that Liferay is pleased to be selected for&nbsp; Novell Market Start.&rdquo;<br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <br />For more about Liferay Portal and the coming version 4.3
column27: visit <a href="http://www.liferay.com">www.liferay.com</a>.&nbsp; Additional information about Novell Market Start can be found at www.novell.com/linux/marketstart.<br /><strong><br /></strong><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong><br />Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column28: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. Liferay clients include Discovery Education
column30: and the Christian Science Monitor. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles. For more information
column31: please visit <a href="http://www.liferay.com">www.liferay.com</a>. </em></p><div align="center"># # # #</div><p><br /><strong>Press Contact:</strong><br />S&amp;S Public Relations

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><div align="justify"><div align="center"><strong>Liferay Portal 4.3 Now Available</strong><br /><em>Latest Release Further Enhances Usability and Performance</em></div><br /><strong>LOS ANGELES &ndash; (JUNE 28
column15: provider of the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise-class
column17: today announced the release of Liferay Portal 4.3. The latest version of the award-winning portal features a revamped user interface and improvements in performance.<br /><br />&ldquo;In the last several months we&rsquo;ve focused on making our portal easier than ever to use
column19: Liferay&rsquo;s founder and Chief Software Architect.&nbsp; &ldquo;Users will see a marked difference from our previous versions in the visual and interactive experience.&rdquo;<br /><br />Among several features enhancing the user experience is Liferay Portal&rsquo;s new Freeform or &ldquo;WebOS&rdquo; theme
column20: which mirrors the look and feel of a standard desktop environment. Portal applications (portlets) can now be moved
column22: and resized as users wish without restriction for a more intuitive working environment. Liferay Portal 4.3 also introduces the Web 2.0 convention of tagging
column23: bringing user-driven content categorization to the enterprise. Administrators will welcome the reduced effort in managing content while still retaining control over how much users can do in the portal.<br /><br />An assortment of other user-centered features round out the new release
column24: including:<br /><br /><ul><li><em>Portal Publishing &amp; Staging </em>&ndash; Staging allows administrators to preview changes to portal pages before publishing those changes to a live public page.</li><li><em>Federated Search </em>&ndash; Liferay Portal leverages Amazon&rsquo;s OpenSearch to return search results in one result set from multiple sources including Liferay portlets and external applications.</li><li><em>Sitemaps Protocol Support </em>&ndash; Sitemaps makes newly added pages instantaneously searcheable by all major search engines without additional configuration.</li><li><em>Open ID</em> &ndash; OpenID stores all of a user&rsquo;s information in one place and provides part of it (as approved by the user) to the websites where the user wants to participate. This makes it much easier to protect user information and keep it up to date. For website owners
column25: OpenID facilitates end user registration by negating the effort it takes to register in a website.</li><li><em>Multiple Enterprise Management </em>&ndash; This allows an organization to run multiple enterprise portals from just one installation of Liferay
column26: each with its own distinct communities
column27: branding and set up as defined by the administrators.</li><li><em>Mobile Device Support </em>&ndash; Content and pages in Liferay Portal can now be accessed via mobile devices including Blackberrys
column29: and mobile phones.</li></ul><br />Technical users will also appreciate performance enhancements in the new version. Liferay Portal has been streamlined to leverage the Spring framework more deeply to eliminate the need for EJBs
column30: and tuning of the persistence layer has further improved scalability and reduced system requirements. Liferay Portal 4.3 also adds new tools to simplify the development process:<br /><br /><ul><li>Liferay Eclipse Plug-In&mdash; Version 4.3 includes a custom-built Eclipse plug-in that speeds up portlet development by performing traditionally manual setup processes.</li><li>Liferay Software Catalog&mdash;The software catalog connects to remote portlet and theme repositories
column31: keeping track of new and updated offerings and enabling them to be instantly installed or updated without restarting the server.</li></ul>In development since 2000
column32: Liferay is a popular platform among developers thanks to its flexible architecture and compatibility with today&rsquo;s best technologies. It is being used at some of the world&rsquo;s largest enterprises as a solution to a variety of business issues
column33: ranging from data management with the built in content management system to organizational productivity and communication with Liferay&rsquo;s full suite of collaboration tools.<br /><br />&ldquo;We drew from both client and community feedback for this release
column35: &ldquo;Liferay is fortunate to have such a large and active community supporting and driving innovation.&rdquo;<br /><br />Version 4.3 is available at no cost under the MIT license and is available for immediate download at <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/downloads">www.liferay.com/web/guest/downloads</a>.&nbsp; <br /><br /><br /><em><strong>About Liferay:</strong></em><br /><em>Liferay Portal is the world&rsquo;s leading enterprise open source portal framework with Fortune 500 clients in the U.S. and Europe. Liferay Professional Services offers technical support
column36: custom development and professional training to ensure successful deployment of its flagship product in the most demanding IT environments. The company is headquartered in Los Angeles. For more information
column37: please visit www.liferay.com.</em><br /><em><br /></em><div align="center">--#</div><br /><strong>Contact:</strong><br />S&amp;S Public Relations
column39: 847-955-0700 ext. 9333<br /><a href="mailto:cgutwillig@sspr.com">cgutwillig@sspr.com</a></div></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

    <dynamic-content><h1>5.0 - Spurgeon</h1> <h2>Architecture</h2> <ul> <li>Lifelets Framework</li> <li>Simple Remote Portlets</li> <li>Enhanced Microformat Support</li> <li>Complete AJAX Page Loading / Refresh</li> <li>Massive Usability Improvements</li> </ul> <h2>Identity Management</h2> <ul> <li>Full LDAP Synchronization</li> <li>Per-Community LDAP Configuration</li> </ul> <h2>Integration</h2> <ul> <li>Jasper Reports</li> <li>Pentaho</li> <li>Intalio</li> </ul> <h2>Portlets</h2> <ul> <li>Refactor UI for existing Portlets - a focus on usability</li> <li>Calendar - Produce / Consume iCal feeds (i.e. Remote Calendaring
column16: Calendar Subscriptions)</li> <li>Chatroom</li> </ul> <h2>Blog Improvements</h2> <ul> <li>RSS Feed</li> <li>User / Guest Comments</li> <li>Browsable Categories</li> <li>Tags / Labels</li> <li>Entry Rating System</li> </ul> <h2>Refactor Wiki Portlet</h2> <ul> <li>Adopt Media Wiki Syntax</li> </ul></dynamic-content>\n  </dynamic-element>\n</root>'

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<root default-locale="en_US" available-locales="en_US">
  <dynamic-element name="content" type="text_area">
    <dynamic-content language-id="en_US"><h1>Documents</h1> <table width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" class="cd-docfiles-table"> <tbody> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">&nbsp;</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">View</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">Download</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">Contribute</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation Guide</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_installation_guide/onepage">One page</a><br /> <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_installation_guide/multipage/">Multi-page</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_installation_guide.pdf">PDF</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Liferay_4_Installation_Guide_Contributions">LiferayPedia</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title"><strong>Customization Guide</strong></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_customization_guide/onepage/">One page</a><br /> <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_customization_guide/multipage/">Multi-page</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/installation/liferay_4_customization_guide.pdf">PDF</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Liferay_4_Customization_Guide_Contributions">LiferayPedia</a></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <h1>Lifecasts</h1> <p>The following videos show information related to the installation and initial configuration of the portal. Also a video of the demo is listed for those who want to preview Liferay Portal before installing.</p> <table width="100%" height="30" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" class="cd-docfiles-table"> <tbody> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Alfresco Setup</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Integrate Liferay Portal with Alfresco CMS.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/alfresco.swf">Full Screen<br /> (7.08mb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">CAS Setup</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Integrate Liferay Portal with a CAS server to access multiple applications with a single sign on.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/cas.swf">Full Screen<br /> (9.67mb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Chat Portlet Setup</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Set up the Chat Portlet to enhance collaboration.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/chat_portlet_setup.swf">Full Screen<br /> (2.44mb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">LDAP Integration</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>A tutorial on LDAP integration.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/ldap_.swf">Full Screen<br /> (7.22mb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Learn how to quickly install Liferay 4.0.0 in a few easy steps. Watch the installation of JDK 5.0 and Liferay bundled with Tomcat.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/installation.swf">Full Screen<br /> (5.16mb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Demo Liferay Portal</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Create an account to explore the Liferay Portal demo.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/installation.swf">Full Screen<br /> (6.61mb)</a></td> </tr> </tbody> </table></dynamic-content>

class="cd-docfiles-header">&nbsp;</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">View</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">Download</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-header">Contribute</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Portlet Development</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/devel/liferay_4_portlet_development_guide/onepage">One page</a><br /> <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/devel/liferay_4_portlet_development_guide/multipage/">Multi-page</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/devel/liferay_4_extension_environment_guide/onepage/">One page</a><br /> <a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.2/doc/devel/liferay_4_extension_environment_guide/multipage/">Multi-page</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/devzone/javadocs">Javadoc</a></td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://wiki.liferay.com/index.php/Liferay_4_Javadoc_Contributions">LiferayPedia</a></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p><a name="lifecasts"></a></p> <h1>Lifecasts</h1> <p>The following videos show how to use different tools included in Liferay</p> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" class="cd-docfiles-table"> <tbody> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Ext Enviroment</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>The Ext Environment allows you to extend and modify the source code without breaking your upgrade path to new versions of Liferay Portal.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4.0.0/flash/tutorials/ext_environment.swf">Full Screen<br /> (8.02mb)</a></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p><a name="presentations"></a></p> <h1>Presentations</h1> <p>The following presentations cover installation and portlet development. We also offer <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/services/training">public and private training sessions</a> that offer more in-depth coverage over a broader range of <a href="http://www.liferay.com/web/guest/services/training/chicago/course_topics">topics</a>.</p> <table width="100%" height="30" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" class="cd-docfiles-table"> <tbody> <tr valign="bottom"> <td class="cd-docfiles-section" colspan="4">Installing the Development Environment</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation 1</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Basic Setup -&nbsp;The first step of the installation process.&nbsp; It is not advised to skip ahead because each section builds off the previous one.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/installation/installation-1-basic-setup.ppt">Download<br /> (415kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation 2</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Required Tools - Setting up Jikes and Ant</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/installation/installation-2-required-tools.ppt">Download<br /> (160kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation 3</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Ext Environment - The extension environment allows developers to extend the Liferay Portal source code without breaking their upgrade path.&nbsp; Always use the extension environment to make modifications to the source code.</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/installation/installation-3-ext-environment.ppt">Download<br /> (437kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Installation 4</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Database Connection -&nbsp;Configuring Liferay to use MySQL as the database.</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/installation/installation-4-database-connection.ppt">Download<br /> (342kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr valign="bottom"> <td class="cd-docfiles-section" colspan="4">Eclipse</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Eclipse 1</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Create a New Project - Setting up Liferay as a project in Eclipse IDE.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/eclipse/eclipse-1-create-a-new-project.ppt">Download<br /> (489kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Eclipse 2</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Set up the Debugger - This will teach you how to set breakpoints inside your classes and step through them.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/eclipse/eclipse-2-set-up-the-debugger.ppt">Download<br /> (707kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr valign="bottom"> <td class="cd-docfiles-section" colspan="4">JSP Portlet</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">JSP Portlet 1</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description"> <p>Basic Portlet - This is a good starting point if you are new to Liferay.&nbsp;It will help you learn the basic&nbsp;file and directory&nbsp;structure you will need to know to develop portlets within Liferay.</p> </td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/jsp-portlet/jsp-portlet-1-basic-portlet.ppt">Download<br /> (272kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">JSP Portlet 2</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Title and Category - Adding a title and category using Language-ext.properties and liferay-display.xml.</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/jsp-portlet/jsp-portlet-2-title-and-category.ppt">Download<br /> (128kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr valign="bottom"> <td class="cd-docfiles-section" colspan="4">Struts Portlet</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Struts Portlet 1</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Struts Portlet</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/struts-portlet/struts-portlet-1.ppt">Download<br /> (314kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Struts Portlet 2</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Add an Action</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/struts-portlet/struts-portlet-2.ppt">Download<br /> (227kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Struts Portlet 3</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Database Interaction</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/struts-portlet/struts-portlet-3.ppt">Download<br /> (353kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">Struts Portlet 4</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">Redirect</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/struts-portlet/struts-portlet-4.ppt">Download<br /> (127kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr valign="bottom"> <td class="cd-docfiles-section" colspan="4">JSF Portlet</td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">JSF Introduction</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">JSF Introduction</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-link"><a href="http://content.liferay.com/4/docs/ppt/jsf-portlet/jsf-portlet-introduction.ppt">Download<br /> (137kb)</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="cd-docfiles-title">JSF Portlet A</td> <td class="cd-docfiles-description">A Simple JSF Portlet -
